After studying this Unit, you will be able to 

describe the formation of different types of solutions;   
0 express concentration of solution in different units;   
0 state and explain Henry's law and Raoult's law;

explain deviations of real solutions from Raoult's law; describe colligative properties of solutions and correlate these with molar masses of the solutes; explain abnormal colligative properties exhibited by some solutes in solutions. 

In normal life we rarely come across pure substances. Most of these are mixtures containing two or more pure substances. Their utility or importance in life depends on their composition. For example, the properties of brass (mixture of copper and zinc) are quite different from those of German silver (mixture of copper, zinc and nickel) or bronze (mixture of copper and tin); 1 part per million (ppm) of fluoride ions in water prevents tooth decay, while $1 . 5 ~ \mathrm { p p m }$ causes the tooth to become mottled and high concentrations of fluoride ions can be poisonous (for example, sodium fluoride is used in rat poison); intravenous injections are always dissolved in water containing salts at particular ionic concentrations that match with blood plasma concentrations and so on. 

In this Unit, we will consider mostly liquid solutions and their formation. This wil be followed by studying the properties of the solutions, like vapour pressure and colligative properties. We will begin with types of solutions and then various alternatives in which concentrations of a solute can be expressed in liquid solution. 

Solutions are homogeneous mixtures of two or more than two components. By homogenous mixture we mean that its composition and properties are uniform throughout the mixture. Generally, the component that is present in the largest quantity is known as solvent. Solvent determines the physical state in which solution exists. One or more components present in the solution other than solvent are called solutes. In this Unit we shall consider only binary solutions (i.e., consisting of two components). Here each component may be solid, liquid or in gaseous state and are summarised in Table 1.1. 

Composition of a solution can be described by expressing its concentration. The latter can be expressed either qualitatively or quantitatively. For example, qualitatively we can say that the solution is dilute (i.e., relatively very small quantity of solute) or it is concentrated (i.e., relatively very large quantity of solute). But in real life these kinds of description can add to lot of confusion and thus the need for a quantitative description of the solution. 

There are several ways by which we can describe the concentration of the solution quantitatively. 

(i) Mass percentage (w/w): The mass percentage of a component of a solution is defined as: Mass $\%$ of a component 

For example, if a solution is described by $1 0 \%$ glucose in water by mass, it means that $1 0 \ \mathrm { g }$ of glucose is dissolved in $9 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ of water resulting in a $1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ solution. Concentration described by mass percentage is commonly used in industrial chemical applications. For example, commercial bleaching solution contains 3.62 mass percentage of sodium hypochlorite in water. 

(ii) Volume percentage $( V / V )$ : The volume percentage is defined as: Volume $\%$ of a component $=$ Volume of the component ×100 Total volume of solution 

For example, $1 0 \%$ ethanol solution in water means that $1 0 \ \mathrm { \ m L }$ of ethanol is dissolved in water such that the total volume of the solution is $1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { { m L } }$ . Solutions containing liquids are commonly expressed in

1.3 Solubility 

Solubility of a substance is its maximum amount that can be dissolved in a specified amount of solvent at a specified temperature. It depends upon the nature of solute and solvent as well as temperature and pressure. Let us consider the effect of these factors in solution of a solid or a gas in a liquid. 

1.3.1 Solubility of a Solid in a Liquid 

Every solid does not dissolve in a given liquid. while sodium chloride and sugar dissolve readily in water, naphthalene and anthracene do not. On the other hand, naphthalene and anthracene dissolve readily in benzene but sodium chloride and sugar do not. It is observed that polar solutes dissolve in polar solvents and non polar solutes in nonpolar solvents. In general, a solute dissolves in a solvent if the intermolecular interactions are similar in the two or we may say like dissolves like. 

when a solid solute is added to the solvent, some solute dissolves and its concentration increases in solution. This process is known as dissolution. Some solute particles in solution collide with the solid solute particles and get separated out of solution. This process is known as crystallisation. A stage is reached when the two processes occur at the same rate. Under such conditions, number of 'solute particles going into solution will be equal to the solute particles separating out and a state of dynamic equilibrium is reached. 

Solute $^ +$ Solvent Solution 

At this stage the concentration of solute in solution will remain constant under the given conditions, i.e., temperature and pressure. Similar process is followed when gases are dissolved in liquid solvents. Such a solution in which no more solute can be dissolved at the same temperature and pressure is called a saturated solution. An unsaturated solution is one in which more solute can be dissolved at the same temperature. The solution which is in dynamic equilibrium with undissolved solute is the saturated solution and contains the maximum amount of solute dissolved in a given amount of solvent. Thus, the concentration of solute in such a solution is its solubility. 

Earlier we have observed that solubility of one substance into another depends on the nature of the substances. In addition to these variables, two other parameters, i.e., temperature and pressure also control this phenomenon.

Thus, the concentration of solute in such a solution is its solubility. 

Earlier we have observed that solubility of one substance into another depends on the nature of the substances. In addition to these variables, two other parameters, i.e., temperature and pressure also control this phenomenon. 

Effect of temperature 

The solubility of a solid in a liquid is significantly affected by temperature changes. Consider the equilibrium represented by equation 1.10. This, being dynamic equilibrium, must follow Le Chateliers Principle. In general, if in a nearly saturated solution, the dissolution process is endothermic $( \Delta _ { \mathrm { s o l } } \ \mathrm { ~ H ~ } > \ 0 )$ , the solubility should increase with rise in temperature and if it is exothermic $( \Delta _ { \mathrm { s o l } } \ \mathrm { H } < 0 )$ the solubility should decrease. These trends are also observed experimentally. 

Effect of pressure 

Pressure does not have any significant effect on solubility of solids in liquids. It is so because solids and liquids are highly incompressible and practically remain unaffected by changes in pressure. 

1.3.2 Solubility of a Gas in a Liquid 

Many gases dissolve in water. Oxygen dissolves only to a small extent in water. It is this dissolved oxygen which sustains all aquatic life. On the other hand, hydrogen chloride gas (HCl) is highly soluble in water. Solubility of gases in liquids is greatly affected by pressure and temperature. The solubility of gases increase with increase of pressure. For solution of gases in a solvent, consider a system as shown in Fig. 1.1 (a). The lower part is solution and the upper part is gaseous system at pressure $p$ and temperature $T .$ Assume this system to be in a state of dynamic equilibrium, i.e., under these conditions rate of gaseous particles entering and leaving the solution phase is the same. Now increase the pressure over the solution phase by compressing the gas to a smaller volume [Fig. 1.1 (b)]. This will increase the number of gaseous particles per unit volume over the solution and also the rate at which the gaseous particles are striking the surface of solution to enter it. The solubility of the gas will increase until a new equilibrium is reached resulting in an increase in the pressure of a gas above the solution and thus its solubility increases. 

Henry was the first to give a quantitative relation between pressure and solubility of a gas in a solvent which is known as Henry's law. The law states that at a constant temperature, the solubility of a gas in a liquid is directly proportional to the partial pressure of the gas present above the surface of liquid or solution. Dalton, a contemporary of Henry, also concluded independently that the solubility of a gas in a liquid solution is a function of partial pressure of the gas. If we use the mole fraction of a gas in the solution as a measure of its solubility, then it can be said that the mole fraction of gas in the solution is proportional to the partial pressure of the gas over the solution. The most commonly used form of Henry's law states that "the partial pressure of the gas in vapour phase $\pmb { \left[ p \right] }$ is proportional to the mole fraction of the gas $\pmb { \left\{ x \right\} }$ in the solution" and is expressed as: 

Here $K _ { \mathrm { H } }$ is the Henry's law constant. If we draw a graph between partial pressure of the gas versus mole fraction of the gas in solution, then we should get a plot of the type as shown in Fig. 1.2.

It is obvious from equation (1.11) that higher the value of $K _ { \mathrm { H } }$ at a given pressure, the lower is the solubility of the gas in the liquid. It can be seen from Table 1.2 that $\mathrm { K } _ { \mathrm { H } }$ values for both $\Nu _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { { O } } _ { 2 }$ increase with increase of temperature indicating that the solubility of gases increases with decrease of temperature. It is due to this reason that aquatic species are more comfortable in cold waters rather than in warm waters. -

Henry's law finds several applications in industry and explains some biological phenomena. Notable among these are: 

• To increase the solubility of $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ in soft drinks and soda water, the bottle is sealed under high pressure. • Scuba divers must cope with high concentrations of dissolved gases while breathing air at high pressure underwater. Increased pressure increases the solubility of atmospheric gases in blood. when the divers come towards surface, the pressure gradually decreases. This releases the dissolved gases and leads to the formation of bubbles of nitrogen in the blood. This blocks capillaries and creates a medical condition known as bends, which are painful and dangerous to life. 

To avoid bends, as well as, the toxic effects of high concentrations of nitrogen in the blood, the tanks used by scuba divers are filled with air diluted with helium $. 1 1 . 7 \%$ helium, $5 6 . 2 \%$ nitrogen and $3 2 . 1 \%$ oxygen). 

• At high altitudes the partial pressure of oxygen is less than that at the ground level. This leads to low concentrations of oxygen in the blood and tissues of people living at high altitudes or climbers. Low blood oxygen causes climbers to become weak and unable to think clearly, symptoms of a condition known as anoxia. 

Effect of Temperature 

Solubility of gases in liquids decreases with rise in temperature. when dissolved, the gas molecules are present in liquid phase and the process of dissolution can be considered similar to condensation and heat is evolved in this process. We have learnt in the last Section that dissolution process involves dynamic equilibrium and thus must follow Le Chatelier's Principle. As dissolution is an exothermic process, the solubility should decrease with increase of temperature.

1.4 Vapour Oressure of Liquid Solutions 

Liquid solutions are formed when solvent is a liquid. The solute can be a gas, a liquid or a solid. Solutions of gases in liquids have already been discussed in Section 1.3.2. In this Section, we shall discuss the solutions of liquids and solids in a liquid. Such solutions may contain one or more volatile components. Generally, the liquid solvent is volatile. The solute may or may not be volatile. We shall discuss the properties of only binary solutions, that is, the solutions containing two components, namely, the solutions of (i) liquids in liquids and (i) solids in liquids.

1.4.1 Vapour Pressure of LiquidLiquid Solutions 

Let us consider a binary solution of two volatile liquids and denote the two components as 1 and 2. when taken in a closed vessel, both the components would evaporate and eventually an equilibrium would be established between vapour phase and the liquid phase. Let the total vapour pressure at this stage be $p _ { \mathrm { t o t a l } }$ and $p _ { 1 }$ and $p _ { 2 }$ be the partial vapour pressures of the two components 1 and 2 respectively. These partial pressures are related to the mole fractions $x _ { 1 }$ and $x _ { 2 }$ of the two components 1 and 2 respectively. 

The French chemist, Francois Marte Raoult (1886) gave the quantitative relationship between them. The relationship is known as the Raoult's law which states that for a solution of volatile liquids, the partial vapour pressure of each component of the solution is directly proportional to its mole fraction present in solution.

1.4.2 Raoult's Law as a special case of Henry's Law 

According to Raoult's law, the vapour pressure of a volatile component in a given solution is given by $p _ { \mathrm { { i } } } ^ { \mathrm { { - } } } = x _ { \mathrm { { i } } } ^ { \mathrm { { } } } { p _ { \mathrm { { i } } } ^ { \mathrm { { 0 } } } }$ . In the solution of a gas in a liquid, one of the components is so volatile that it exists as a gas and we have already seen that its solubility is given by Henry's law which states that 

If we compare the equations for Raoult's law and Henry's law, it can be seen that the partial pressure of the volatile component or gas is directly proportional to its mole fraction in solution. Only the proportionality constant $K _ { \mathrm { H } }$ diff ers from ${ p _ { 1 } } ^ { 0 }$ . Thus, Raoult's law becomes a special case of Henry's law in which $K _ { \mathrm { H } }$ becomes equal to ${ p _ { 1 } } ^ { 0 }$ .

1.4.3 Vapour Pressure of Solutions of Solids in Liquids 

Another important class of solutions consists of solids dissolved in liquid, for example, sodium chloride, glucose, urea and cane sugar in water and iodine and sulphur dissolved in carbon disulphide. Some physical properties of these solutions are quite different from those of pure solvents. For example, vapour pressure. Liquids at a given temperature vapourise and under equilibrium conditions the pressure exerted by the vapours of the liquid over the liquid phase is called vapour pressure [Fig. 1.4 (a)]. In 1a pure liquid the entire surface is occupied by the molecules of the liquid. If a non-volatile solute is added to a solvent to give a solution [Fig. 1.4.(b)], the vapour pressure of the solution is solely from the solvent alone. This vapour pressure of the solution at a given temperature is found to be lower than the vapour pressure of the pure solvent at the same temperature. In the solution, the surface has both solute and solvent molecules; thereby the fraction of the surface covered by the solvent molecules gets reduced. Consequently, the number of solvent molecules escaping from the surface is correspondingly reduced, thus, the vapour pressure is also reduced. 

The decrease in the vapour pressure of solvent depends on the quantity of non-volatile solute present in the solution, irrespective of its nature. For example, decrease in the vapour pressure of water by adding $1 . 0 \ \mathrm { m o l }$ of sucrose to one kg of water is nearly similar to that produced by adding $1 . 0 \ \mathrm { m o l }$ of urea to the same quantity of water at the same temperature. 

Raoult's law in its general form can be stated as, for any solution the partial vapour pressure of each volatile component in the solution is directly proportional to its mole fraction. 

In a binary solution, let us denote the solvent by 1 and solute by 2. When the solute is non-volatile, only the solvent molecules are present in vapour phase and contribute to vapour pressure. Let $p _ { 1 }$ be the vapour pressure of the solvent, $x _ { 1 }$ be its mole fraction, ${ p } _ { \mathrm { i } } ^ { 0 }$ be its vapour pressure in the pure state. Then according to Raoult's law 

The proportionality constant is equal to the vapour pressure of pure solvent, $p _ { 1 } ^ { 0 }$ ; A plot between the vapour pressure and the mole fraction of the solvent is linear (Fig. 1.5). 

1.5 Ideal and Nonideal Solutions 

1.5.1 Ideal Solutions 

Liquid-liquid solutions can be classified into ideal and non-ideal solutions on the basis of Raoult's law. - 

The solutions which obey Raoult's law over the entire range of concentration are known as ideal solutions. The ideal solutions have two other important properties. The enthalpy of mixing of the pure components to form the solution is zero and the volume of mixing is also zero, i.e., 

It means that no heat is absorbed or evolved when the components are mixed. Also, the volume of solution would be equal to the sum of volumes of the two components. At molecular level, ideal behaviour of the solutions can be explained by considering two components A and B. In pure components, the intermolecular attractive interactions will be of types A-A and B-B, whereas

chunk-4e278f6362ce974eb772aa7b3e944d94.content:
py of mixing of the pure components to form the solution is zero and the volume of mixing is also zero, i.e., 

It means that no heat is absorbed or evolved when the components are mixed. Also, the volume of solution would be equal to the sum of volumes of the two components. At molecular level, ideal behaviour of the solutions can be explained by considering two components A and B. In pure components, the intermolecular attractive interactions will be of types A-A and B-B, whereas in the binary solutions in addition to these two interactions, A-B type of interactions will also be present. If the intermolecular attractive forces between the A-A and B-B are nearly equal to those between A-B, this leads to the formation of ideal solution. A perfectly ideal solution is rare but some solutions are nearly ideal in behaviour. Solution of n-hexane and n-heptane, bromoethane and chloroethane, benzene and toluene, etc. fall into this category. 

1.5.2 Non-ideal Solutions 

When a solution does not obey Raoult's law over the entire range of concentration, then it is called non-ideal solution. The vapour pressure of such a solution is either higher or lower than that predicted by Raoult's law (equation 1.16). If it is higher, the solution exhibits positive deviation and if it is lower, it exhibits negative deviation from Raoult's law. The plots of vapour pressure as a function of mole fractions for such solutions are shown in Fig. 1.6. 

The cause for these deviations lie in the nature of interactions at the molecular level. In case of positive deviation from Raoult's law, A-B interactions are weaker than those between A-A or B-B, i.e., in this case the intermolecular attractive forces between the solute-solvent molecules are weaker than those between the solute-solute and solvent-solvent molecules. This means that in such solutions, molecules of A (or B) will find it easier to escape than in pure state. This will increase the vapour pressure and result in positive deviation. Mixtures of ethanol and acetone behave in this manner. In pure ethanol, molecules are hydrogen bonded. On adding acetone, its molecules get in between the host molecules and break some of the hydrogen bonds between them. Due to weakening of interactions, the solution shows positive deviation from Raoult's law [Fig. 1.6 (a)]. In a solution formed by adding carbon disulphide to acetone, the dipolar interactions between solute-solvent molecules are weaker than the respective interactions among the solute-solute and solvent-solvent molecules. This solution also shows positive deviation. 

In case of negative deviations from Raoult's law, the intermolecular attractive forces between A-A and B-B are weaker than those between A-B and leads to decrease in vapour pressure resulting in negative deviations. An example of this type is a mixture of phenol and aniline. In this case the intermolecular hydrogen bonding between phenolic proton and lone pair on nitrogen atom of aniline is stronger than the respective intermolecular hydrogen bonding between similar molecules. Similarly, a mixture of chloroform and acetone forms a solution with negative deviation from Raoult's law. This is because chloroform molecule is able to form hydrogen bond with acetone molecule as shown. 

This decreases the escaping tendency of molecules for each component and consequently the vapour pressure decreases resulting in negative deviation from Raoult's law [Fig. 1.6. (b)]. 

Some liquids on mixing, form azeotropes which are binary mixtures having the same composition in liquid and vapour phase and boil at a constant temperature. In such cases, it is not possible to separate the components by fractional distillation. There are two types of azeotropes called minimum boiling azeotrope and maximum boiling

chunk-c99e9f9a17b49c995083dfd9e169808b.content:
escaping tendency of molecules for each component and consequently the vapour pressure decreases resulting in negative deviation from Raoult's law [Fig. 1.6. (b)]. 

Some liquids on mixing, form azeotropes which are binary mixtures having the same composition in liquid and vapour phase and boil at a constant temperature. In such cases, it is not possible to separate the components by fractional distillation. There are two types of azeotropes called minimum boiling azeotrope and maximum boiling azeotrope. The solutions which show a large positive deviation from Raoult's law form minimum boiling azeotrope at a specific composition. 

For example, ethanol-water mixture (obtained by fermentation of sugars) on fractional distillation gives a solution containing approximately $9 5 \%$ by volume of ethanol. Once this composition, known as azeotrope composition, has been achieved, the liquid and vapour have the same composition, and no further separation occurs. 

The solutions that show large negative deviation from Raoult's law form maximum boiling azeotrope at a specific composition. Nitric acid and water is an example of this class of azeotrope. This azeotrope has the approximate composition, $6 8 \%$ nitric acid and $3 2 \%$ water by mass, with a boiling point of 393.5 K.

1.6 Colligative Properties and Determination of Molar Mass 

We have learnt in Section 1.4.3 that the vapour pressure of solution decreases when a non-volatile solute is added to a volatile solvent. There are many properties of solutions which are connected with this decrease of vapour pressure. These are: (1) relative lowering of vapour pressure of the solvent (2) depression of freezing point of the solvent (3) elevation of boiling point of the solvent and (4) osmotic pressure of the solution. All these properties depend on the number of solute particles irrespective of their nature relative to the total number of particles present in the solution. Such properties are called colligative properties (colligative: from Latin: co means together, ligare means to bind). In the following Sections we will discuss these properties one by one.

We have learnt in Section 1.4.3 that the vapour pressure of a solvent in solution is less than that of the pure solvent. Raoult established that the lowering of vapour pressure depends only on the concentration of the solute particles and it is independent of their identity. 1.6.2 Elevation of Boiling Point 

The vapour pressure of a liquid increases with increase of temperature. It boils at the temperature at which its vapour pressure is equal to the atmospheric pressure. For example, water boils at 373.15 K $\mathrm { ( 1 0 0 ^ { \circ } C ) }$ because at this temperature the vapour pressure of water is 1.013 bar (1 atmosphere). We have also learnt in the last section that vapour pressure of the solvent decreases in the presence of non-volatile solute. Fig. 1.7 depicts the variation of vapour pressure of the pure solvent and solution as a function of temperature. For example, the vapour pressure of an aqueous solution of sucrose is less than 1.013 bar at 373.15 K. In order to make this solution boil, its vapour pressure must be increased to 1.013 bar by raising the temperature above the boiling temperature of the pure solvent (water). Thus, the boiling point of a solution is

1.6.3 Depression of Freezing Point 

The lowering of vapour pressure of a solution causes a lowering of the freezing point compared to that of the pure solvent (Fig. 1.8). We know that at the freezing point of a substance, the solid phase is in dynamic equilibrium with the liquid phase. Thus, the freezing point of a substance may be defined as the temperature at which the vapour pressure of the substance in its liquid phase is equal to its vapour pressure in the solid phase. A solution will freeze when its vapour pressure equals the vapour pressure of the pure solid solvent as is clear from Fig. 1.8. According to Raoult's law, when a non-volatile solid is added to the solvent its vapour pressure decreases and now it would become equal to that of solid solvent at lower temperature. Thus, the freezing point of the solvent decreases. 

Let $T _ { \mathrm { f } } ^ { 0 }$ be the freezing point

1.6.4 0smosis and Osmotic Pressure 

There are many phenomena which we observe in nature or at home. For example, raw mangoes shrivel when pickled in brine (salt water); wilted flowers revive when placed in fresh water, blood cells collapse when suspended in saline water, etc. If we look into these processes we 

find one thing common in all, that is, all these substances are bound by membranes. These membranes can be of animal or vegetable origin and these occur naturally such as pig's bladder or parchment or can be synthetic such as cellophane. These membranes appear to be continuous sheets or films, yet they contain a network of submicroscopic holes or pores. Small solvent 

molecules, like water, can pass through these holes but the passage of bigger

chunk-89e74523720c0b67cf34a73a6de43ba0.content:
etc. If we look into these processes we 

find one thing common in all, that is, all these substances are bound by membranes. These membranes can be of animal or vegetable origin and these occur naturally such as pig's bladder or parchment or can be synthetic such as cellophane. These membranes appear to be continuous sheets or films, yet they contain a network of submicroscopic holes or pores. Small solvent 

molecules, like water, can pass through these holes but the passage of bigger molecules like solute is hindered. Membranes having this kind of properties are known as semipermeable membranes (SPM). 

Assume that only solvent molecules can pass through these semipermeable membranes. If this membrane is placed between the solvent and solution as shown in Fig. 1.9, the solvent molecules will flow through the membrane from pure solvent to the solution. This process of flow of the solvent is called osmosis. 

The flow will continue till the equilibrium is attained. The flow of the solvent from its side to solution side across a semipermeable membrane can be stopped if some extra pressure is applied on the solution. This pressure that just stops the flow of solvent is called osmotic pressure of the solution. The flow of solvent from dilute solution to the concentrated solution across a semipermeable membrane is due to osmosis. The important point to be kept in mind is that solvent molecules always flow from lower concentration to higher concentration of solution. The osmotic pressure has been found to depend on the concentration of the solution. 

The osmotic pressure of a solution is the excess pressure that must be applied to a solution to prevent osmosis, i.e., to stop the passage of solvent molecules through a semipermeable membrane into the solution. This is illustrated in Fig. 1.10. Osmotic pressure is a colligative property as it depends on the number of solute molecules and not on their identity. For dilute solutions, it has been found experimentally that osmotic pressure is proportional to the molarity, $\pmb { c }$ of the solution at a given temperature $\pmb { T }$ Thus: 

Here $\Pi$ is the osmotic pressure and $\mathrm { R }$ is the gas constant. 

Here $V$ is volume of a solution in litres containing $\mathbf { n } _ { 2 }$ moles of solute. If $\mathbf { w } _ { 2 }$ grams of solute, of molar mass, $M _ { 2 }$ is present in the solution, then $n _ { 2 } = \mathrm { w } _ { 2 } \ / \ M _ { 2 }$ and we can write, 

Thus, knowing the quantities $\mathbf { w } _ { 2 }$ , $T , \Pi$ and $V$ we can calculate the molar mass of the solute. 

Measurement of osmotic pressure provides another method of determining molar masses of solutes. This method is widely used to determine molar masses of proteins, polymers and other macromolecules. The osmotic pressure method has the advantage over other methods as pressure measurement is around the room temperature and the molarity of the solution is used instead of molality. As compared to other colligative properties, its magnitude is large even for very dilute solutions. The technique of osmotic pressure for determination of molar mass of solutes is particularly useful for biomolecules as they are generally not stable at higher temperatures and polymers have poor solubility. 

Two solutions having same osmotic pressure at a given temperature are called isotonic solutions. When such solutions are separated by semipermeable membrane no osmosis occurs between them. For example, the osmotic pressure associated with the fluid inside the blood cell is equivalent to that of $0 . 9 \%$ (mass/volume) sodium chloride

molar mass of solutes is particularly useful for biomolecules as they are generally not stable at higher temperatures and polymers have poor solubility. 

Two solutions having same osmotic pressure at a given temperature are called isotonic solutions. When such solutions are separated by semipermeable membrane no osmosis occurs between them. For example, the osmotic pressure associated with the fluid inside the blood cell is equivalent to that of $0 . 9 \%$ (mass/volume) sodium chloride solution, called normal saline solution and it is safe to inject intravenously. On the other hand, if we place the cells in a solution containing more than $0 . 9 \%$ (mass/ volume) sodium chloride, water will flow out of the cells and they would shrink. Such a solution is called hypertonic. If the salt concentration is less than $0 . 9 \%$ (mass/volume), the solution is said to be hypotonic. In this case, water will flow into the cells if placed in this solution and they would swell. •

The phenomena mentioned in the beginning of this section can be explained on the basis of osmosis. A raw mango placed in concentrated salt solution loses water via osmosis and shrivel into pickle. Wilted flowers revive when placed in fresh water. A carrot that has become limp because of water loss into the atmosphere can be placed into the water making it firm once again. Water will move into its cells through osmosis. When placed in water containing less than $0 . 9 \%$ (mass/ volume) salt, blood cells swell due to flow of water in them by osmosis. People taking a lot of salt or salty food experience water retention in tissue cells and intercellular spaces because of osmosis. The resulting puffiness or swelling is called edema. Water movement from soil into plant roots and subsequently into upper portion of the plant is partly due to osmosis. The preservation of meat by salting and of fruits by adding sugar protects against bacterial action. Through the process of osmosis, a bacterium on salted meat or candid fruit loses water, shrivels and dies. 

1.6.5 Reverse Osmosis and water Purification 

The direction of osmosis can be reversed if a pressure larger than the osmotic pressure is applied to the solution side. That is, now the pure solvent flows out of the solution through the semi permeable membrane. This phenomenon is called reverse osmosis and is of great practical utility. Reverse osmosis is used in desalination of sea water. A schematic set up for the process is shown in Fig. 1.11. 

When pressure more than osmotic pressure is applied, pure water is squeezed out of the sea water through the membrane. A variety of polymer membranes are available for this purpose. 

The pressure required for the reverse osmosis is quite high. A workable porous membrane is a film of cellulose acetate placed over a suitable support. Cellulose acetate is permeable to water but impermeable to impurities and ions present in sea water. These days many countries use desalination plants to meet their potable water requirements.

Molecules of ethanoic acid (acetic acid) dimerise in benzene due to hydrogen bonding. This normally happens in solvents of low dielectric constant. In this case the number of particles is reduced due to dimerisation. Association of molecules is depicted as follows: 

It can be undoubtedly stated here that if all the molecules of ethanoic acid associate in benzene, then $\Delta T _ { \mathrm { b } }$ or $\Delta T _ { \mathrm { f } }$ for ethanoic acid will be half of the normal value. The molar mass calculated on the basis of this $\Delta T _ { \mathrm { b } }$ or $\Delta T _ { \mathrm { f } }$ will, therefore, be twice the expected value. Such a molar mass that is either lower or higher than the expected or normal value is called as abnormal molar mass. 

In l880 van't Hoff introduced a factor i, known as the van't Hoff factor, to account for the extent of dissociation or association. This factor i is defined as: - 

Normal molar mass Abnormal molar mass blis Observed colligative property Calculated colligative property i Total number of moles of particles after association/dissociation Number of moles of particles before association/dissociation 

Here abnormal molar mass is the experimentally determined molar mass and calculated colligative properties are obtained by assuming that the non-volatile solute is neither associated nor dissociated. In case of association, value of i is less than unity while for dissociation it is greater than unity. For example, the value of i for aqueous KCl solution is close to 2, while the value for ethanoic acid in benzene is nearly 0.5. 

Inclusion of van't Hoff factor modifies the equations for colligative properties as follows: 

Relative lowering of vapour pressure of solvent,

A solution is a homogeneous mixture of two or more substances. Solutions are classified as solid, liquid and gaseous solutions. The concentration of a solution is expressed in terms of mole fraction, molarity, molality and in percentages. The dissolution of a gas in a liquid is governed by Henry's law, according to which, at a given temperature, the solubility of a gas in a liquid is directly proportional to the partial pressure of the gas. The vapour pressure of the solvent is lowered by the presence of a non-volatile solute in the solution and this lowering of vapour pressure of the solvent is governed by Raoult's law, according to which the relative lowering of vapour pressure of the solvent over a solution is equal to the mole fraction of a non-volatile solute present in the solution. However, in a binary liquid solution, if both the components of the solution are volatile then another form of Raoult's law is used. Mathematically, this form of the Raoult's law is stated as: $p _ { \mathrm { t o t a l } } = p _ { \mathrm { 1 } } ^ { \mathrm { 0 } } x _ { \mathrm { 1 } } + p _ { \mathrm { 2 } } ^ { \mathrm { 0 } } x _ { \mathrm { 2 } }$ . Solutions which obey Ra

chunk-dbb7f44d2458b3e3cda0608234ef0866.content:
is used. Mathematically, this form of the Raoult's law is stated as: $p _ { \mathrm { t o t a l } } = p _ { \mathrm { 1 } } ^ { \mathrm { 0 } } x _ { \mathrm { 1 } } + p _ { \mathrm { 2 } } ^ { \mathrm { 0 } } x _ { \mathrm { 2 } }$ . Solutions which obey Raoult's law over the entire range of concentration are called ideal solutions. Two types of deviations from Raoult's law, called positive and negative deviations are observed. Azeotropes arise due to very large deviations from Raoult's law. 

The properties of solutions which depend on the number of solute particles and are independent of their chemical identity are called colligative properties. These are lowering of vapour pressure, elevation of boiling point, depression of freezing point and osmotic pressure. The process of osmosis can be reversed if a pressure higher than the osmotic pressure is applied to the solution. Colligative properties have been used to determine the molar mass of solutes. Solutes which dissociate in solution exhibit molar mass lower than the actual molar mass and those which associate show higher molar mass than their actual values. 

Quantitatively, the extent to which a solute is dissociated or associated can be expressed by van't Hoff factor i. This factor has been defined as ratio of normal molar mass to experimentally determined molar mass or as the ratio of observed colligative property to the calculated colligative property.

Liquid Solutions include oxygen dissolved in water (gas in liquid) and ethanol or glucose dissolved in water (liquid or solid in liquid). Solid Solutions examples are hydrogen in palladium (gas in solid) and amalgams like mercury with sodium or copper dissolved in gold (solid in solid). The table illustrates the diversity of binary solutions by showing how solutes and solvents of different states combine, supporting the surrounding content's explanation of solution types and their formation. It emphasizes the concept that solutions are homogeneous mixtures with uniform properties, and the examples link directly to real-life applications such as gas mixtures in the atmosphere, aqueous solutions, and metal alloys. The table also implicitly supports the discussion on expressing concentration by showing the physical states involved, which influence how concentration units like mass percentage or mole fraction are applied. chunk-e7c75629454b22fcd70841fa2e1b8939.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
x _ { \mathrm { A } } = { \frac { n _ { \mathrm { A } } } { n _ { \mathrm { A } } + ~ n _ { \mathrm { B } } } }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation $x_{\mathrm{A}} = \frac{n_{\mathrm{A}}}{n_{\mathrm{A}} + n_{\mathrm{B}}}$ defines the mole fraction of component A in a binary mixture composed of components A and B. Here, $n_{\mathrm{A}}$ and $n_{\mathrm{B}}$ represent the number of moles of components A and B respectively. The mole fraction $x_{\mathrm{A}}$ is a dimensionless quantity representing the ratio of moles of A to the total moles in the solution. This equation employs basic arithmetic operations of addition and division. It is fundamental in solution chemistry for quantitatively describing composition, especially when dealing with mixtures of two components. The mole fraction is crucial in thermodynamics and physical chemistry, as it directly relates to properties such as vapor pressure, colligative properties, and chemical potential. It also serves as a basis for more complex calculations involving multi-component systems, where the sum of all mole fractions equals unity. Practically, it is used in chemical engineering, pharmaceuticals, and environmental science to characterize solution concentrations precisely. Within the broader context of the discussion, this equation exemplifies a quantitative measure of concentration, complementing other concentration units like mass percentage, volume percentage, and molarity, thereby providing a comprehensive framework for solution composition analysis.
chunk-e7c75629454b22fcd70841fa2e1b8939.modal_entity_name: Mole Fraction in a Binary Mixture (equation)

chunk-4211df949fbb80f4dbe02a80bee09513.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
x _ { \mathrm { i } } = { \frac { n _ { \mathrm { i } } } { n _ { \mathrm { 1 } } + \ n _ { \mathrm { 2 } } + \ldots \ldots \ldots + n _ { \mathrm { i } } } } = { \frac { n _ { \mathrm { i } } } { \sum n _ { \mathrm { i } } } }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation defines the mole fraction, denoted as x_i, of a component i in a multi-component solution. Mathematically, it is the ratio of the number of moles of component i (n_i) to the total number of moles of all components present in the solution, expressed as the sum \( \sum n_i \). The variables n_i represent the amount of substance in moles for each component i, where i ranges over all components in the mixture. The mole fraction is a dimensionless quantity ranging from 0 to 1, and the sum of mole fractions for all components equals unity, reflecting the partitioning of the total mole count among components. This equation employs basic arithmetic operations: division and summation. In the context of solution chemistry, mole fraction is a fundamental concentration measure used to describe the composition of mixtures quantitatively. It is particularly significant in thermodynamics and physical chemistry for relating solution composition to properties such as vapor pressure, boiling point elevation, and freezing point depression. The mole fraction concept is closely related to other concentration units like mass percentage, volume percentage, and molarity, but it uniquely facilitates mole-based calculations and ideal mixture assumptions. Practically, mole fractions are used in chemical engineering, environmental science, and pharmaceuticals to model mixture behavior, reaction stoichiometry, and gas mixtures. Within the broader framework of the text, this equation provides a rigorous quantitative basis for describing solution composition, enabling precise calculations and predictions of solution properties beyond qualitative descriptors like 'dilute' or 'concentrated'.

chunk-ea2b11dc6c313f740e05822a39413a03.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
x _ { 1 } + x _ { 2 } + \ldots + \ldots . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation $x_1 + x_2 + \ldots = 1$ represents the fundamental property of mole fractions in a multi-component solution. Here, $x_i$ denotes the mole fraction of the $i$-th component, defined as the ratio of the number of moles of that component to the total number of moles of all components in the solution. The summation of all mole fractions equals unity, reflecting the partitioning of the total mole count among all constituents. This equation uses summation notation implicitly, indicating that the sum over all components' mole fractions is exactly one. The mole fraction is a dimensionless quantity, crucial in thermodynamics and solution chemistry for describing composition. It facilitates calculations involving colligative properties, vapor pressure, and chemical equilibria. The equation is foundational in the context of solution concentration measures, linking mole-based composition to physical properties and enabling conversion between different concentration units. It also underpins the quantitative description of mixtures in chemical engineering, physical chemistry, and related fields, providing a normalized measure of component proportions that is invariant to total solution amount. This normalization is essential for comparing compositions and predicting mixture behavior under various conditions.
chunk-ea2b11dc6c313f740e05822a39413a03.modal_entity_name: Sum of Mole Fractions in a Solution (equation)

chunk-e68636908b1db33e27ce05b34b2aef50.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { r } { \mathbf { x } _ { \mathrm { g l y c o l } } = \frac { \mathrm { m o l e s ~ o f ~ \mathbf { C } _ 2 H _ 6 \mathbf { O } _ 2 ~ } } { \mathrm { m o l e s ~ o f ~ \mathbf { C } _ 2 H _ 6 \mathbf { O } _ 2 ~ } + \mathrm { m o l e s ~ o f ~ H _ 2 O ~ } } } \\ { \cdot \mathrm { ~  ~ { \stackrel { ~ \right. ~ } { ~ \left. ~ } } ~ } } \\ { = \frac { \mathrm { 0 . 3 2 2 m o l } } { \mathrm { 0 . 3 2 2 m o l } + 4 . 4 4 4 \mathrm { m o l } } = \ 0 . 0 6 8 } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation represents the mole fraction of ethylene glycol (C2H6O2) in a binary solution composed of ethylene glycol and water. Mathematically, the mole fraction x_glycol is defined as the ratio of the number of moles of ethylene glycol to the total number of moles of all components in the solution, i.e., ethylene glycol plus water. Here, the numerator is the moles of ethylene glycol (0.322 mol), and the denominator is the sum of moles of ethylene glycol and water (0.322 mol + 4.444 mol). The resulting mole fraction, 0.068, is a dimensionless quantity between 0 and 1. The variables are: moles of C2H6O2 (ethylene glycol) and moles of H2O (water), both expressed in moles. The operations used include division and addition, fundamental arithmetic operations in ratio calculations. This mole fraction is crucial in physical chemistry and solution thermodynamics, as it quantifies the relative amount of a component in a mixture, independent of volume or mass. It is particularly useful for relating solution composition to physical properties such as vapor pressure, boiling point elevation, and freezing point depression. The equation is part of a broader discussion on concentration units and solution composition metrics, illustrating how mole fraction provides a precise and temperature-independent measure of concentration compared to mass or volume percentages. Practically, mole fraction calculations are essential in chemical engineering, pharmaceuticals, and environmental science for designing mixtures, predicting solution behavior, and analyzing reaction equilibria. This equation exemplifies the fundamental concept of mole fraction in solution chemistry, linking molecular quantities to macroscopic solution properties.

chunk-f4d182abc2643a5d448d31ef1b921303.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\mathrm { M o l a r i t y } = { \frac { \mathrm { M o l e s ~ o f ~ s o l u t e } } { \mathrm { V o l u m e ~ o f ~ s o l u t i o n ~ i n ~ l i t r e } } }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation defines molarity (M), a fundamental concentration measure in chemistry, as the ratio of the number of moles of solute to the volume of the solution expressed in liters. Mathematically, molarity is given by M = n / V, where n represents the amount of solute in moles, and V is the total volume of the solution in liters. This ratio quantifies how many moles of solute are present per liter of solution, enabling precise stoichiometric calculations. The variables are: 'Moles of solute' (n), which is the amount of substance measured in moles, and 'Volume of solution in litre' (V), the total solution volume including solute and solvent. The operation is a simple division, reflecting a density-like measure of solute concentration. Molarity is widely used in analytical chemistry, solution preparation, and reaction stoichiometry, especially where volume measurements are convenient. It contrasts with other concentration units like molality or mole fraction, which depend on mass or mole ratios rather than volume. The equation's physical significance lies in its temperature dependence, as solution volume can vary with temperature, affecting molarity values. Within the broader context of solution concentration units discussed, molarity provides a practical and commonly used metric for expressing solution strength, particularly in laboratory and industrial chemical processes.

chunk-c35998b050691cacf242541a22149835.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { l } { { \mathrm { M o l a r i t y } = { \frac { 0 . 1 2 5 ~ { \mathrm { m o l } } \times 1 0 0 0 ~ { \mathrm { m L } } { \mathrm { L } } ^ { - 1 } } { 4 5 0 ~ { \mathrm { m L } } } } = 0 . 2 7 8 ~ { \mathrm { M } } } } \\ { { \phantom { \mathrm { M o l a r i t y } } } } \\ { { \phantom { \mathrm { M o l a r i t y } } = 0 . 2 7 8 ~ { \mathrm { m o l } } ~ { \mathrm { L } } ^ { - 1 } } } \\ { { \phantom { \mathrm { M o l a r i t y } } } } \\ { { \phantom { \mathrm { = } } 0 . 2 7 8 ~ { \mathrm { m o l } } ~ { \mathrm { d } } { \mathrm { m } } ^ { - 3 } } } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation represents the calculation of molarity (M), a fundamental concentration unit in chemistry defined as the number of moles of solute per liter of solution. Here, molarity is computed by dividing the amount of solute in moles (0.125 mol) multiplied by the conversion factor from milliliters to liters (1000 mL/L) by the volume of the solution in milliliters (450 mL). The resulting value, 0.278 mol/L, quantifies the concentration of NaOH in the solution. Variables include the moles of solute (0.125 mol), volume of solution (450 mL), and the unit conversion factor (1000 mL/L). The operations involve multiplication and division, converting volume units and calculating molarity. This equation is situated in the context of solution concentration units, illustrating how molarity relates to other concentration measures like mass percent and mole fraction. Molarity is temperature-dependent due to volume changes, distinguishing it from mass-based concentration units. The equation's physical significance lies in its use for preparing and characterizing chemical solutions, essential in laboratory and industrial processes. It connects to broader discussions on solution concentration by providing a precise, volumetric-based measure, facilitating stoichiometric calculations and reaction planning. Practical applications include chemical synthesis, pharmaceutical formulation, and analytical chemistry, where accurate concentration knowledge is critical.

chunk-ee59741b919b65b8663340a944b97b51.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\mathrm { M o l a l i t y ~ ( m ) } = \frac { \mathrm { M o l e s ~ o f ~ s o l u t e } } { \mathrm { M a s s ~ o f ~ s o l v e n t ~ i n ~ k g } }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation defines molality (m) as the ratio of the number of moles of solute to the mass of the solvent expressed in kilograms. Mathematically, molality is given by m = n_solute / m_solvent, where n_solute represents the amount of solute in moles, calculated by dividing the mass of the solute by its molar mass, and m_solvent is the mass of the solvent in kilograms. This ratio is a concentration measure independent of temperature and pressure since it relies on mass rather than volume. The equation involves fundamental operations of division and unit conversion (grams to kilograms). In the context of solution chemistry, molality is crucial for expressing solution concentration, especially when temperature variations affect volume but not mass. It complements other concentration measures such as molarity and mole fraction, providing a stable parameter for colligative property calculations and thermodynamic analyses. The equation's theoretical significance lies in its role in quantifying solute concentration relative to solvent mass, facilitating precise stoichiometric and physical property predictions in chemical solutions. Practically, it is used in preparing solutions with specific properties, studying freezing point depression, boiling point elevation, and vapor pressure lowering. Within the broader framework of solution concentration expressions, this equation highlights the importance of mass-based concentration metrics in chemical and physical chemistry.

These points form a linear trend ascending from the origin towards the upper right corner of the graph, demonstrating a direct proportionality between the mole fraction and the partial pressure. A straight line is drawn through the data points, representing the best fit or trend line, which confirms Henry's law that the partial pressure of a gas above a solution is proportional to its mole fraction in the solution. The slope of this line corresponds to the Henry's law constant (K_H) for HCl gas in cyclohexane at 293 K. The graph is cleanly designed with clear axis labels and a title at the top reading "Fig. 1.2: Experimental results for the solubility of HCl gas in cyclohexane at 293 K." chunk-d3bd6806c852091dadc4eb7c0e5adc2c.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
p = K _ { \mathrm { H } } \ x
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation p = K_H x represents Henry's law, which quantitatively relates the partial pressure p of a gas above a liquid to the mole fraction x of the gas dissolved in the liquid at equilibrium and constant temperature. Here, p denotes the partial pressure of the gas in the vapor phase, x is the mole fraction of the gas dissolved in the solvent, and K_H is Henry's law constant, a proportionality factor dependent on the nature of the gas and temperature. Mathematically, this is a linear relationship indicating direct proportionality between gas solubility and its partial pressure. The equation involves simple multiplication, reflecting a first-order dependence without higher-order or nonlinear terms. In the context of gas solubility in liquids, this law is fundamental for understanding how gases dissolve under varying pressures, especially in aqueous solutions. Physically, it embodies the dynamic equilibrium between gas molecules entering and leaving the solution, governed by molecular interactions and thermodynamic principles. The constant K_H encapsulates the affinity of the gas for the solvent and varies with temperature, typically increasing with temperature, which corresponds to decreased solubility. This equation is closely related to concepts of dynamic equilibrium, partial pressure, mole fraction, and thermodynamic solubility. Practically, it is applied in environmental science (e.g., oxygen solubility in water sustaining aquatic life), industrial processes (carbonation of beverages), and physiological contexts (scuba diving gas absorption). Within the broader framework of solubility phenomena, this equation complements the discussion on how temperature and pressure influence solubility, specifically highlighting the distinct behavior of gases compared to solids in liquids.

Footnotes: None Analysis: The table titled 'Table 1.2: Values of Henry's Law Constant for Some Selected Gases in Water' is organized into two parallel columns of data, each listing gases, their corresponding temperatures in Kelvin, and their Henry's law constants (K_H) expressed in kbar. The left side lists gases such as Helium (He), Hydrogen (H_2), Nitrogen (N_2), and Oxygen (O_2) at temperatures 293 K and 303 K, while the right side lists Argon, Carbon Dioxide (CO_2), Formaldehyde, Methane, and Vinyl chloride at 298 K or 298-299 K. The Henry's law constant (K_H) quantifies the proportionality between the partial pressure of a gas and its mole fraction in solution, with higher K_H values indicating lower solubility. Key data points include: Helium has a high K_H of 144.97 kbar at 293 K, indicating low solubility; Nitrogen's K_H increases from 76.48 kbar at 293 K to 88.84 kbar at 303 K, showing decreased solubility with temperature rise; Oxygen's K_H increases from 34.86 kbar at 293 K to 46.82 kbar at 303 K, consistent with the temperature effect; CO_2 has a very low K_H of 1.67 kbar at 298 K, indicating high solubility; Formaldehyde and Methane have extremely low K_H values (1.83×10^-5 and 0.413-0.611 kbar respectively), suggesting very high solubility. Statistical trends reveal that for diatomic gases like N_2 and O_2, K_H increases with temperature, confirming the inverse relationship between solubility and temperature. The variation in K_H among gases at similar temperatures reflects the influence of gas nature on solubility, supporting the text's assertion that K_H depends on gas identity. The table's data directly supports the surrounding content's explanation of Henry's law, illustrating how different gases dissolve in water under varying temperatures and pressures. The relationship between temperature and K_H values in the table exemplifies the exothermic nature of gas dissolution, as higher temperatures reduce solubility (higher K_H). This explains biological phenomena such as aquatic species' preference for cold water and the medical implications for scuba divers due to gas solubility changes with pressure and temperature. The table also underpins industrial applications like carbonation of soft drinks and the use of helium in diving tanks to mitigate nitrogen toxicity. Overall, the table concretely illustrates Henry's law constants for various gases, reinforcing the theoretical concepts and practical examples discussed in the surrounding text about gas solubility, temperature effects, and pressure relationships in aqueous solutions.
chunk-149877d873b47e7a15340d1b82f277e2.modal_entity_name: Henry's Law Constants for Selected Gases in Water (table)

chunk-bc507e212db27612561273ad0ec9c4a0.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
x \ : { \mathrm { ( N i t r o g e n ) } } \ : = \ : { \frac { p \ : { \mathrm { ( n i t r o g e n ) } } } { K _ { \mathrm { H } } } } \ : = \ : { \frac { 0 . 9 8 7 { \mathrm { b a r } } } { 7 6 . 4 8 0 { \mathrm { b a r } } } } = 1 . 2 9 \times 1 0 ^ { - 5 }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: This equation represents Henry's law expressed mathematically for nitrogen gas dissolved in water. It states that the mole fraction x of nitrogen gas in the aqueous solution is equal to the ratio of the partial pressure p of nitrogen gas above the solution to Henry's law constant K_H for nitrogen at the given temperature. Here, x is the mole fraction of nitrogen in the liquid phase (dimensionless), p is the partial pressure of nitrogen gas in bar, and K_H is Henry's law constant in bar, characterizing the solubility of nitrogen in water at 293 K. The equation uses a simple division operation to relate gas phase pressure to solubility in the liquid phase, reflecting a direct proportionality between solubility and partial pressure. This formulation is fundamental in physical chemistry and chemical engineering for quantifying gas solubility in liquids under equilibrium conditions. The constant K_H depends on temperature and the nature of the gas, indicating that solubility decreases with increasing temperature for nitrogen. The equation is applied in contexts such as calculating dissolved gas amounts in water, understanding aquatic life conditions, and industrial processes involving gas-liquid equilibria. It connects to broader concepts of gas solubility, partial pressures, and equilibrium thermodynamics, and serves as a basis for practical applications like carbonation of beverages, scuba diving safety, and environmental science. The numerical example demonstrates how to compute the mole fraction from known pressure and Henry's constant, illustrating the quantitative use of Henry's law in real-world scenarios.
chunk-bc507e212db27612561273ad0ec9c4a0.modal_entity_name: Henry's Law for Nitrogen Gas Solubility (equation)

chunk-f035d5115cad334c4a2a2983a045f2ea.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
p _ { 2 } = { p _ { 2 } } ^ { 0 } x _ { 2 }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation p_2 = p_2^0 x_2 represents Raoult's law for the partial vapor pressure of component 2 in a binary liquid solution. Mathematically, it states that the partial vapor pressure (p_2) of component 2 above the solution is directly proportional to its mole fraction (x_2) in the liquid phase, with the proportionality constant being the vapor pressure of the pure component 2 (p_2^0) at the same temperature. Here, p_2 is the partial vapor pressure of component 2 in the solution, p_2^0 is the vapor pressure of pure component 2, and x_2 is the mole fraction of component 2 in the liquid solution. The operation involved is a simple scalar multiplication reflecting linear proportionality. This equation is fundamental in physical chemistry and solution thermodynamics, describing how the composition of a liquid mixture affects the vapor pressures of its constituents. It is applied in contexts such as distillation, solvent evaporation, and understanding solution volatility. The equation relates to Dalton's law of partial pressures, which states that total vapor pressure is the sum of partial pressures, and to the broader framework of Raoult's law which applies to ideal solutions. Physically, it signifies that the presence of a solute reduces the escaping tendency of solvent molecules proportionally to their mole fraction. Practically, it helps predict vapor-liquid equilibria, design separation processes, and analyze solution behavior under varying compositions. Within the broader discussion, this equation forms the basis for understanding vapor pressures in binary liquid mixtures and is essential for interpreting experimental data and calculating total vapor pressures and vapor phase compositions.
chunk-f035d5115cad334c4a2a2983a045f2ea.modal_entity_name: Raoult's Law for Partial Vapor Pressure of Component 2 (equation)

chunk-af3374c572765d3266f2c34e58dab3c5.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
p _ { \mathrm { t o t a l } } = p _ { \mathrm { 1 } } + p _ { \mathrm { 2 } }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation $p_{\mathrm{total}} = p_1 + p_2$ represents the total vapor pressure of a binary liquid solution as the sum of the partial vapor pressures of its two volatile components. Here, $p_{\mathrm{total}}$ denotes the total vapor pressure exerted by the solution in equilibrium with its vapor phase, while $p_1$ and $p_2$ are the partial vapor pressures of components 1 and 2, respectively. These partial pressures are directly proportional to the mole fractions $x_1$ and $x_2$ of the components in the liquid phase, following Raoult's law: $p_1 = p_1^0 x_1$ and $p_2 = p_2^0 x_2$, where $p_1^0$ and $p_2^0$ are the vapor pressures of the pure components at the same temperature. The equation embodies Dalton's law of partial pressures, which states that the total pressure of a gas mixture is the sum of the partial pressures of individual gases. This relationship is fundamental in physical chemistry for understanding solution behavior, phase equilibria, and volatility. It allows prediction of how the total vapor pressure changes with composition, which is crucial in distillation, solvent extraction, and chemical engineering processes. The equation connects to broader concepts such as dynamic equilibrium, mole fraction, and vapor-liquid equilibrium, providing a quantitative framework for analyzing binary solutions of volatile liquids.
chunk-af3374c572765d3266f2c34e58dab3c5.modal_entity_name: Total Vapor Pressure of a Binary Liquid Solution (equation)

chunk-558b298dc870119ca36709b9b0d5eb31.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
{ \begin{array} { r l } & { p _ { \mathrm { t o t a l } } = x _ { 1 } { p _ { 1 } } ^ { 0 } + x _ { 2 } { p _ { 2 } } ^ { 0 } } \\ & { \qquad = ( 1 - x _ { 2 } ) { p _ { 1 } } ^ { 0 } + x _ { 2 } { p _ { 2 } } ^ { 0 } } \\ & { \qquad = { p _ { 1 } } ^ { 0 } + \left( { p _ { 2 } } ^ { 0 } - { p _ { 1 } } ^ { 0 } \right) x _ { 2 } } \end{array} }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: This equation represents Raoult's law for the total vapor pressure of a binary liquid solution composed of two volatile components. Mathematically, it expresses the total vapor pressure (p_total) as a linear combination of the partial vapor pressures of the two components, weighted by their mole fractions in the liquid phase. Here, x_1 and x_2 denote the mole fractions of components 1 and 2 respectively, with the constraint x_1 + x_2 = 1. The terms p_1^0 and p_2^0 represent the vapor pressures of the pure components 1 and 2 at the same temperature. The equation is derived by substituting p_1 = x_1 p_1^0 and p_2 = x_2 p_2^0 into Dalton's law of partial pressures, yielding p_total = x_1 p_1^0 + x_2 p_2^0. Re-expressing x_1 as (1 - x_2) leads to the linear form p_total = p_1^0 + (p_2^0 - p_1^0) x_2, highlighting the linear dependence of total vapor pressure on the mole fraction of component 2. This linearity is fundamental in physical chemistry for understanding solution behavior, phase equilibria, and volatility. The equation applies in contexts such as predicting vapor pressures in liquid mixtures, designing distillation processes, and analyzing solution thermodynamics. It also connects to Dalton's and Henry's laws, illustrating the interplay between mole fractions and partial pressures. Practically, it aids in calculating vapor pressures of mixtures, determining composition of vapor phases, and optimizing industrial separation techniques. Within the broader framework, this equation exemplifies the quantitative relationship between composition and vapor pressure in ideal solutions, serving as a foundational principle in solution chemistry and thermodynamics.
chunk-558b298dc870119ca36709b9b0d5eb31.modal_entity_name: Raoult's Law for Total Vapor Pressure of Binary Solutions (equation)

chunk-f75062e5f433c72d19894ba1c01ea662.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { r } { p _ { 1 } = y _ { 1 } \ p _ { \mathrm { t o t a l } } } \\ { p _ { 2 } = y _ { 2 } \ p _ { \mathrm { t o t a l } } } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The given equations, p_1 = y_1 * p_total and p_2 = y_2 * p_total, express the partial pressures of components 1 and 2 in the vapor phase in terms of their mole fractions (y_1 and y_2) in the vapor and the total vapor pressure (p_total) above the solution. Here, p_1 and p_2 denote the partial pressures of components 1 and 2 respectively, y_1 and y_2 are the mole fractions of these components in the vapor phase, and p_total is the sum of all partial pressures in the vapor phase, consistent with Dalton's law of partial pressures. The equations use simple multiplication to relate mole fractions to partial pressures, reflecting the proportionality inherent in ideal gas mixtures. These relations are fundamental in physical chemistry and thermodynamics, particularly in the study of vapor-liquid equilibrium (VLE) of binary solutions. They provide a quantitative link between the composition of the vapor phase and the total pressure, enabling calculation of vapor phase composition from measured or calculated partial pressures. This is crucial for understanding distillation, evaporation, and other separation processes. The equations complement Raoult's law, which relates partial pressures to mole fractions in the liquid phase, thereby bridging liquid and vapor phase compositions. In the broader framework, these equations facilitate the analysis of solution volatility, phase equilibria, and the design of chemical processes involving mixtures, such as solvent recovery and purification.

chunk-6730ccc5219832f46f6da80f646d89ac.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
p _ { \mathrm { i } } = y _ { \mathrm { i } } p _ { \mathrm { t o t a l } }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation p_i = y_i p_total represents the partial pressure of component i in a vapor phase in equilibrium with a liquid solution. Here, p_i denotes the partial pressure of component i, y_i is the mole fraction of component i in the vapor phase, and p_total is the total vapor pressure above the solution. Mathematically, this is a direct application of Dalton's law of partial pressures, which states that the total pressure exerted by a gaseous mixture is the sum of the partial pressures of each individual component. The mole fraction y_i serves as a weighting factor indicating the proportion of component i in the vapor phase. This linear relationship implies that the partial pressure of each component is proportional to its mole fraction in the vapor. The equation is fundamental in thermodynamics and physical chemistry for describing phase equilibria, particularly vapor-liquid equilibrium (VLE). It connects the composition of the vapor phase to measurable pressures, enabling the determination of vapor phase composition from total pressure and vice versa. This equation complements Raoult's law, which relates the partial pressure of a component to its mole fraction in the liquid phase and the pure component vapor pressure. Together, these laws allow calculation of vapor pressures and compositions in binary or multicomponent solutions, as illustrated in the surrounding context with chloroform and dichloromethane mixtures. The physical significance lies in predicting how volatile components distribute between liquid and vapor phases, critical for distillation, solvent recovery, and chemical process design. The equation also underpins the understanding that the vapor phase is richer in the more volatile component, as the mole fraction y_i in vapor reflects volatility differences. Overall, this equation is a cornerstone in the quantitative description of vapor-liquid equilibria and is essential for practical applications in chemical engineering, environmental science, and materials processing.
chunk-6730ccc5219832f46f6da80f646d89ac.modal_entity_name: Partial Pressure in Vapor Phase via Dalton's Law (equation)

chunk-97a565fb29191dc7fe7cfa41dfe02b9e.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\mathrm { M o l e s \ o f \ C H _ { 2 } C l _ { 2 } } \qquad = \ { \frac { 4 0 \ \mathrm { g } } { 8 5 \ \mathrm { g \ m o l ^ { - 1 } } } } \ = \ 0 . 4 7 \ \mathrm { m o l }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: This equation calculates the number of moles of dichloromethane (CH2Cl2) present in a given mass of 40 grams by dividing the mass by the molar mass (85 g/mol). The variable represents the amount of substance in moles, a fundamental unit in chemistry quantifying the number of molecules or atoms. The operation used is simple division, converting mass to moles, which is essential for mole fraction calculations in solution chemistry. In the context of vapor pressure and Raoult's law, determining moles allows computation of mole fractions, which directly influence partial vapor pressures of components in a solution. This calculation is critical for applying Dalton's and Raoult's laws to predict total vapor pressure and vapor phase composition in binary mixtures. It bridges mass-based measurements to mole-based thermodynamic properties, enabling quantitative analysis of solution behavior and phase equilibria. The equation exemplifies the foundational step in relating physical quantities to chemical thermodynamics and vapor-liquid equilibrium studies.

chunk-061dd79e1b86dfb1713028cf54068ebe.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { r l } { x _ { \mathrm { C H _ { 2 } C l _ { 2 } } } } & { = \mathrm { \small ~ \displaystyle \frac { 0 . 4 7 ~ m o l } { 0 . 6 8 3 ~ m o l } ~ \delta ~ } = \mathrm { \small ~ 0 . 6 8 8 } } \\ { x _ { \mathrm { C H C l _ { 3 } } } } & { = \mathrm { \small ~ 1 . 0 0 ~ - ~ 0 . 6 8 8 } = \mathrm { \small ~ 0 . 3 1 2 } } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The given equations represent the mole fractions of two components, dichloromethane (CH2Cl2) and chloroform (CHCl3), in a binary liquid solution. Mathematically, the mole fraction x_i of a component i is defined as the ratio of the number of moles of that component to the total number of moles in the solution. Here, x_{CH2Cl2} = 0.47 mol / 0.683 mol = 0.688 and x_{CHCl3} = 1.00 - 0.688 = 0.312, ensuring the mole fractions sum to unity. These mole fractions are dimensionless quantities that quantify the relative composition of each component in the liquid phase. The mole fractions serve as fundamental variables in Raoult's law, which relates the partial vapor pressure of each component to its mole fraction and pure component vapor pressure. This linear relationship underpins the calculation of total vapor pressure and vapor phase composition in ideal solutions. The equations are crucial for applying Dalton's and Raoult's laws to predict vapor-liquid equilibrium, enabling the determination of vapor pressures and vapor phase mole fractions, as demonstrated in the example with chloroform and dichloromethane at 298 K. The mole fraction concept is central to solution thermodynamics, phase equilibria, and chemical engineering processes such as distillation and solvent extraction. In the broader framework, these mole fractions link the microscopic composition of the liquid phase to macroscopic measurable properties like vapor pressure, facilitating quantitative analysis of solution behavior and volatility differences between components.

chunk-8339e064492eb7ad1356970ded4ed820.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
{ \begin{array} { r l } { p _ { \mathrm { t o t a l } } } & { = p _ { 1 } ^ { ~ 0 } + ( p _ { 2 } ^ { ~ 0 } - p _ { 1 } ^ { ~ 0 } ) ~ x _ { 2 } = 2 0 0 + ( 4 1 5 - 2 0 0 ) \times 0 . 6 8 8 } \\ & { = 2 0 0 + 1 4 7 . 9 = 3 4 7 . 9 ~ { \mathrm { m m ~ H g } } } \end{array} }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: This equation represents the total vapor pressure (p_total) of a binary liquid solution as a function of the mole fraction of component 2 (x_2) in the solution, based on Raoult's law. Mathematically, it expresses p_total as a linear interpolation between the vapor pressures of the pure components, p_1^0 and p_2^0, weighted by the mole fraction x_2. Here, p_1^0 and p_2^0 denote the vapor pressures of pure components 1 and 2 respectively at a given temperature, and x_2 is the mole fraction of component 2 in the liquid phase. The equation uses basic arithmetic operations: addition, subtraction, and multiplication, reflecting the linear dependence of total vapor pressure on composition. This formulation is grounded in Dalton's law of partial pressures and Raoult's law, which states that the partial vapor pressure of each component in an ideal solution is proportional to its mole fraction times its pure component vapor pressure. The physical significance lies in predicting how the total vapor pressure changes with solution composition, crucial for understanding phase equilibria in binary mixtures. The example calculation given (200 + (415 - 200) * 0.688 = 347.9 mm Hg) applies this to a chloroform-dichloromethane mixture at 298 K, illustrating the practical use in chemical engineering and physical chemistry for designing separation processes and analyzing solution behavior. This equation connects to broader thermodynamic concepts such as ideal solution behavior, partial pressures, and vapor-liquid equilibrium, serving as a foundational model before considering deviations in real solutions.

chunk-f2dbe7cfb2677c06488be04de8b43569.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
p = K _ { \mathrm { H } } x .
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation p = K_H x represents Henry's law, which mathematically expresses the proportionality between the partial pressure (p) of a gas above a liquid and its mole fraction (x) dissolved in the liquid. Here, p denotes the partial vapor pressure of the gas component in the solution, x is the mole fraction of the gas dissolved in the liquid phase, and K_H is Henry's law constant, a proportionality factor characteristic of the specific gas-liquid system at a given temperature. The equation is linear, indicating that the gas solubility in the liquid is directly proportional to its partial pressure in the vapor phase. This relationship is fundamental in physical chemistry and chemical engineering for describing gas solubility equilibria. In the surrounding context, Henry's law is discussed alongside Raoult's law, highlighting that Raoult's law is a special case of Henry's law where the proportionality constant K_H equals the vapor pressure of the pure component (p_i^0). The equation is significant in understanding vapor-liquid equilibria, especially for volatile components and gas solubility in liquids, and is applied in calculating vapor pressures and mole fractions in vapor phases of solutions. It also underpins the theoretical framework for ideal and non-ideal solution behavior, influencing practical applications such as distillation, solvent extraction, and environmental modeling of gas absorption.

chunk-50e1ed397bb4dddf53e0892cdfbaeddc.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { l } { { p _ { 1 } \propto x _ { 1 } } } \\ { { p _ { 1 } = x _ { 1 } p _ { 1 } ^ { 0 } } } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation expresses Raoult's law for the vapor pressure of a solvent in a binary solution, mathematically stating that the partial vapor pressure p_1 of the solvent is directly proportional to its mole fraction x_1 in the solution. Specifically, p_1 = x_1 p_1^0, where p_1^0 is the vapor pressure of the pure solvent. Here, p_1 represents the partial vapor pressure exerted by the solvent molecules in the vapor phase at equilibrium, x_1 is the mole fraction of the solvent in the liquid phase, and p_1^0 is a constant characteristic of the pure solvent at the given temperature. The proportionality reflects the linear dependence of vapor pressure on solvent concentration in ideal solutions, where intermolecular interactions between solvent and solute molecules are similar to those in the pure components. The equation involves basic algebraic operations and proportionality concepts. It is fundamental in physical chemistry and thermodynamics for describing ideal solution behavior, vapor-liquid equilibrium, and colligative properties. The equation serves as a special case of Henry's law when the proportionality constant equals the pure solvent vapor pressure. It underpins the classification of solutions into ideal and non-ideal, and deviations from this law indicate molecular interaction differences leading to positive or negative deviations. Practically, it is used to predict vapor pressures in mixtures, design separation processes like distillation, and understand solution properties in chemical engineering and materials science. Within the broader framework, this equation provides a baseline for analyzing solution behavior, interpreting deviations, and connecting molecular interactions to macroscopic thermodynamic properties.
