chunk-e61b00cbb67b93ab5661de3f7e509478.content:
Objectives 

After studying this Unit, you will be able to 

● describe an electrochemical cell and differentiate between galvanic and electrolytic cells; apply Nernst equation for calculating the emf of galvanic cell and define standard potential of the cell;   
• derive relation between standard potential of the cell, Gibbs energy of cell reaction and its equilibrium constant; define resistivity (p), conductivity (k) and molar conductivity $\left( \boldsymbol { \Lambda } _ { \boldsymbol { m } } \right)$ of ionic solutions; differentiate between ionic (electrolytic) and electronic conductivity; describe the method for measurement of conductivity of electrolytic solutions and calculation of their molar conductivity; justify the variation of conductivity and molar conductivity of solutions with change in their concentration and define $A _ { m } ^ { \circ }$ (molar conductivity at zero concentration or infinite dilution); enunciate Kohlrausch law and learn its applications; understand quantitative aspects of electrolysis; describe the construction of some primary and secondary batteries and fuel cells; explain corrosion as an elertrochemical nrocess 

Chemical reactions can be used to produce electrical energy, conversely, electrical energy can be used to carry out chemical reactions that do not proceed spontaneously. 

Electrochemistry is the study of production of electricity from energy released during spontaneous chemical reactions and the use of electrical energy to bring about non-spontaneous chemical transformations. The subject is of importance both for theoretical and practical considerations. A large number of metals, sodium hydroxide, chlorine, fluorine and many other chemicals are produced by electrochemical methods. Batteries and fuel cells convert chemical energy into electrical energy and are used on a large scale in various instruments and devices. The reactions carried out electrochemically can be energy efficient and less polluting. Therefore, study of electrochemistry is important for creating new technologies that are ecofriendly. The transmission of sensory signals through cells to brain and vice versa and communication between the cells are known to have electrochemical origin. Electrochemistry, is therefore, a very vast and interdisciplinary subject. In this Unit, we will cover only some of its important elementary aspects. 

We had studied the construction and functioning of Daniell cell (Fig. 2.1). This cell converts the chemical energy liberated during the redox reaction 

Electron flow 

to electrical energy and has an electrical potential equal to $1 . 1 \mathrm { ~ V ~ }$ when concentration of $Z \mathrm { n } ^ { 2 + }$ and $\mathrm { \Delta C u ^ { 2 + } }$ ions is unity $( 1 ~ \mathrm { m o l } ~ \mathrm { d m } ^ { - 3 } ) ^ { * }$ Such a device is called a galvanic or a voltaic cell. 

If an external opposite potential is applied in the galvanic cell [Fig. 2.2(a)] and increased slowly, we find that the reaction continues to take place till the opposing voltage reaches the value $1 . 1 \mathrm { V }$ [Fig. 2.2(b)] when, the reaction stops altogether and no current flows through the cell. Any further increase in the external potential again starts the reaction but in the opposite direction [Fig. 2.2(c)]. It now functions as an electrolytic cell, a device for using electrical energy to carry non-spontaneous chemical reactions. Both types of cells are quite important and we shall study some of their salient features in the following pages. 

When $\mathrm { E } _ { \mathrm { e x t } } = 1 . 1 ~ \mathrm { V }$ (i) No flow of electrons or current.   
(ii No chemical reaction. 

When $\mathrm { E } _ { \mathrm { e x t } } < 1 . 1$ V (i) Electrons

chunk-c7a4068482d2b0c8789305439bff6f6f.content:
chemical reactions. Both types of cells are quite important and we shall study some of their salient features in the following pages. 

When $\mathrm { E } _ { \mathrm { e x t } } = 1 . 1 ~ \mathrm { V }$ (i) No flow of electrons or current.   
(ii No chemical reaction. 

When $\mathrm { E } _ { \mathrm { e x t } } < 1 . 1$ V (i) Electrons flow from Zn rod to Cu rod hence current flows from Cu to Zn. (ii) $Z \mathrm { n }$ dissolves at anode and copper deposits at cathode. 

As mentioned earlier a galvanic cell is an electrochemical cell that converts the chemical energy of a spontaneous redox reaction into electrical energy. In this device the Gibbs energy of the spontaneous redox reaction is converted into electrical work which may be used for running a motor or other electrical gadgets like heater, fan, geyser, etc. 

Daniell cell discussed earlier is one such cell in which the following redox reaction occurs. 

This reaction is a combination of two half reactions whose addition gives the overall cell reaction: 

These reactions occur in two different portions of the Daniell cell. The reduction half reaction occurs on the copper electrode while the oxidation half reaction occurs on the zinc electrode. These two portions of the cell are also called half-cells or redox couples. The copper electrode may be called the reduction half cell and the zinc electrode, the oxidation half-cell. 

We can construct innumerable number of galvanic cells on the pattern of Daniell cell by taking combinations of different half-cells. Each halfcell consists of a metallic electrode dipped into an electrolyte. The two half-cells are connected by a metallic wire through a voltmeter and a switch externally. The electrolytes of the two half-cells are connected internally through a salt bridge as shown in Fig. 2.1. Sometimes, both the electrodes dip in the same electrolyte solution and in such cases we do not require a salt bridge. 

At each electrode-electrolyte interface there is a tendency of metal ions from the solution to deposit on the metal electrode trying to make it positively charged. At the same time, metal atoms of the electrode have a tendency to go into the solution as ions and leave behind the electrons at the electrode trying to make it negatively charged. At equilibrium, there is a separation of charges and depending on the tendencies of the two opposing reactions, the electrode may be positively or negatively charged with respect to the solution. A potential difference develops between the electrode and the electrolyte which is called electrode potential. When the concentrations of all the species involved in a half-cell is unity then the electrode potential is known as standard electrode potential. According to IUPAC convention, standard reduction potentials are now called standard electrode potentials. In a galvanic cell, the half-cell in which oxidation takes place is called anode and it has a negative potential with respect to the solution. The other half-cell in which reduction takes place is called cathode and it has a positive potential with respect to the solution. Thus, there exists a potential difference between the two electrodes and as soon as the switch is in the on position the electrons flow from negative electrode to positive electrode. The direction of current flow is opposite to that of electron flow. 

The potential difference between the two electrodes of a galvanic cell is called the cell potential and is measured in volts. The cell potential is the difference between the electrode potentials (reduction potentials) of the cathode and anode. It is called the cell electromotive force (emf) of the cell when no current is drawn through the cell. It is now an accepted convention that we keep the anode on the left and the cathode on the right while representing the galvanic cell. A galvanic cell is generally represented by putting a vertical line between metal and electrolyte solution and

chunk-756228e0862eda235c6a4be9e409560d.content:
and is measured in volts. The cell potential is the difference between the electrode potentials (reduction potentials) of the cathode and anode. It is called the cell electromotive force (emf) of the cell when no current is drawn through the cell. It is now an accepted convention that we keep the anode on the left and the cathode on the right while representing the galvanic cell. A galvanic cell is generally represented by putting a vertical line between metal and electrolyte solution and putting a double vertical line between the two electrolytes connected by a salt bridge. Under this convention the emf of the cell is positive and is given by the potential of the halfcell on the right hand side minus the potential of the half-cell on the left hand side i.e., 

This is illustrated by the following example:

The standard electrode potentials are very important and we can extract a lot of useful information from them. The values of standard electrode potentials for some selected half-cell reduction reactions are given in Table 2.1. If the standard electrode potential of an electrode is greater than zero then its reduced form is more stable compared to hydrogen gas. Similarly, if the standard electrode potential is negative then hydrogen gas is more stable than the reduced form of the species. It can be

The standard electrode potentials are very important and we can extract a lot of useful information from them. The values of standard electrode potentials for some selected half-cell reduction reactions are given in Table 2.1. If the standard electrode potential of an electrode is greater than zero then its reduced form is more stable compared to hydrogen gas. Similarly, if the standard electrode potential is negative then hydrogen gas is more stable than the reduced form of the species. It can be seen that the standard electrode potential for fluorine is the highest in the Table indicating that fluorine gas $( \mathrm { F _ { 2 } } )$ has the maximum tendency to get reduced to fluoride ions $( \mathrm { F ^ { - } } )$ and therefore fluorine gas is the strongest oxidising agent and fluoride ion is the weakest reducing agent. Lithium has the lowest electrode potential indicating that lithium ion is the weakest oxidising agent while lithium metal is the most powerful reducing agent in an aqueous solution. It may be seen that as we go from top to bottom in Table 2.1 the standard electrode potential decreases and with this, decreases the oxidising power of the species on the left and increases the reducing power of the species on the right hand side of the reaction. Electrochemical cells are extensively used for determining the pH of solutions, solubility product, equilibrium constant and other thermodynamic properties and for potentiometric titrations. -

It is necessary to define a few terms before we consider the subject of conductance of electricity through electrolytic solutions. The electrical resistance is represented by the symbol $\mathbf { \vec { \nabla } } R \mathbf { \vec { \mu } }$ and it is measured in ohm $\left( \Omega \right)$ which in terms of SI base units is equal to $( \mathrm { k g \ m ^ { 2 } } ) / ( \mathrm { S } ^ { 3 } \ A ^ { 2 } )$ . It can be measured with the help of a wheatstone bridge with which you are familiar from your study of physics. The electrical resistance of any object is directly proportional to its length, l, and inversely proportional to its area of cross section, $A .$ That is, 

The constant of proportionality, p (Greek, rho), is called resistivity (specific resistance). Its SI units are ohm metre $\left( \Omega \mathrm { ~ m } \right)$ and quite often its submultiple, ohm centimetre $\left( \Omega \mathrm { c m } \right)$ is also used. IUPAC recommends the use of the term resistivity over specific resistance and hence in the rest of the book we shall use the term resistivity. Physically, the resistivity for a substance is its resistance when it is one metre long and its area of cross section is one $\mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ . It can be seen that: 

The inverse of resistance, $R _ { : }$ is called conductance, $G$ , and we have the relation: 

The SI unit of conductance is siemens, represented by the symbol $\mathbf { \ddot { S } } ^ { \prime }$ and is equal to $\mathrm { { o h m } ^ { - 1 } }$ (also known as mho) or $\boldsymbol { \Omega } ^ { - 1 }$ . The inverse of resistivity, called conductivity (specific conductance) is represented by the symbol, $\kappa$ (Greek, kappa). IUPAC has recommended the use of term conductivity over specific conductance and hence we shall use the term conductivity

The inverse of resistivity, called conductivity (specific conductance) is represented by the symbol, $\kappa$ (Greek, kappa). IUPAC has recommended the use of term conductivity over specific conductance and hence we shall use the term conductivity in the rest of the book. The SI units of conductivity are $\mathrm { ~ \mathsf ~ { ~ S ~ m ~ } ~ } ^ { - 1 }$ but quite often, $\kappa$ is expressed in $\mathrm { ~ S ~ c m ^ { - 1 } }$ . Conductivity of a material in $\mathrm { S ~ m ^ { - 1 } }$ is its conductance when it is $1 \textrm { m }$ long and its area of cross section is $1 ~ \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ . It may be noted that $1 ~ { \mathrm { S } } ~ { \mathrm { c m } } ^ { - 1 } = ~ 1 0 0 ~ { \mathrm { S } } ~ { \mathrm { m } } ^ { - 1 }$ 

It can be seen from Table 2.2 that the magnitude of conductivity varies a great deal and depends on the nature of the material. It also depends on the temperature and pressure at which the measurements are made. Materials are classified into conductors, insulators and semiconductors depending on the magnitude of their conductivity. Metals and their alloys have very large conductivity and are known as conductors. Certain non-metals like carbon-black, graphite and some organic polymers\* are also electronically conducting. Substances like glass, ceramics, etc., having very low conductivity are known as insulators. Substances like silicon, doped silicon and gallium arsenide having conductivity between conductors and insulators are called semiconductors and are important electronic materials. Certain materials called superconductors by definition have zero resistivity or infinite conductivity. Earlier, only metals and their alloys at very low temperatures (0 to 15 K) were known to behave as superconductors, but nowadays a number of ceramic materials and mixed oxides are also known to show superconductivity at temperatures as high as 150 K. 

Electrical conductance through metals is called metallic or electronic conductance and is due to the movement of electrons. The electronic conductance depends on 

(i) the nature and structure of the metal (ii) the number of valence electrons per atom (ii) temperature (it decreases with increase of temperature). 

As the electrons enter at one end and go out through the other end, the composition of the metallic conductor remains unchanged. The mechanism of conductance through semiconductors is more complex. 

We already know that even very pure water has small amounts of hydrogen and hydroxyl ions $( { \sim } 1 0 ^ { - 7 } \mathrm { M } )$ which lend it very low conductivity $( \mathrm { { 3 . 5 \times 1 0 ^ { - 5 } \mathrm { { S m ^ { - 1 } } } } } )$ ). when electrolytes are dissolved in water, they furnish their own ions in the solution hence its conductivity also increases. The conductance of electricity by ions present in the solutions is called electrolytic or ionic conductance. The conductivity of electrolytic (ionic) solutions depends on: 

(i) the nature of the electrolyte added   
(ii) size of the ions produced and their solvation   
(ii) the nature of the solvent and its viscosity   
(iv) concentration of the electrolyte (v) temperature (it increases with the increase of temperature).

2.4.1 Measurement of the Conductivity of Ionic Solutions 

We know that accurate measurement of an unknown resistance can be performed on a Wheatstone bridge. However, for measuring the resistance of an ionic solution we face two problems. Firstly, passing direct current (DC) changes the composition of the solution. Secondly, a solution cannot be connected to the bridge like a metallic wire or other solid conductor. The first difficulty is resolved by using an alternating current (AC) source of power. The second problem is solved by using a specially designed vessel called conductivity cell. It is available in several designs and two simple ones are shown in Fig. 2.4. 

Basically it consists of two platinum electrodes coated with platinum black (finely divided metallic $\mathrm { P t }$ is deposited on the electrodes electrochemically). These have area of cross section equal to $\cdot _ { A } ,$ and are separated by distance $\mathbf { \nabla } ^ { \cdot } l ^ { \prime }$ . Therefore, solution confined between these electrodes is a column of length $l$ and area of cross section $A$ .The resistance of such a column of solution is then given by the equation: 

The quantity $l / A$ is called cell constant denoted by the symbol, $G ^ { * }$ . It depends on the distance between the electrodes and their area of cross-section and has the dimension of length-' and can be calculated if we know I and A. Measurement of $l$ and $A$ is not only inconvenient but also unreliable. The cell constant is usually determined by measuring the resistance of the cell containing a solution whose conductivity is already known. For this purpose, we generally use KCl solutions whose conductivity is known accurately at various concentrations (Table 2.3) and at different temperatures. The cell constant, $G ^ { * }$ , is then given by the equation: 

Once the cell constant is determined, we can use it for measuring the resistance or conductivity of any solution. The set up for the measurement of the resistance is shown in Fig. 2.5. 

It consists of two resistances $R _ { 3 }$ and $R _ { 4 }$ ,a variable resistance $R _ { 1 }$ and the conductivity cell having the unknown resistance $R _ { 2 }$ .The wheatstone bridge is fed by an oscillator $\mathrm { o }$ (a source of a.c. power in the audio frequency range 550 to 5000 cycles per second). $\mathrm { P }$ is a suitable detector (a headphone or other electronic device) and the bridge is balanced when no current passes through the detector. 2.4.2 Variation of Conductivity and Molar Conductivity with Concentration 

Both conductivity and molar conductivity change with the concentration of the electrolyte. Conductivity always decreases with decrease in concentration both, for weak and strong electrolytes. This can be explained by the fact that the number of ions per unit volume that carry the current in a solution decreases on dilution. The conductivity of a solution at any given concentration is the conductance of one unit volume of solution kept between two platinum electrodes with unit area of cross section and at a distance of unit length. This is clear from the equation: 

$G = \frac { \kappa A } { l } = \kappa$ = k (both A and l are unity in their appropriate units in 1 or cm) 

Molar conductivity of a solution at a given concentration is the conductance of the volume $V$ of solution containing one mole of electrolyte kept between two electrodes with area of cross section $A$ and distance of unit length. Therefore, 

Since $l = 1$ and $A = V$ ( volume containing 1 mole of electrolyte) 

Molar conductivity increases with decrease in concentration. This is because the total volume, $V ,$ of solution containing one mole of electrolyte also increases. It has been found that decrease in $\kappa$ on dilution of a solution is more than compensated by increase in its volume. Physically, it means that at a given concentration, $\Lambda _ { m }$ can be defined as the conductance of the electrolytic solution kept between the electrodes of a conductivity cell at unit distance but having area of cross section large enough to accommodate sufficient volume of solution that contains one mole of the electrolyte. when concentration approaches zero, the molar conductivity is known as limiting molar conductivity and is represented by the symbol $\varLambda _ { m } ^ { \circ }$ .The variation in $\varLambda _ { m }$ with concentration is different (Fig. 2.6) for strong and weak electrolytes.

2.5 Electrolytic Cells and Electrolysis 

In an electrolytic cell external source of voltage is used to bring about a chemical reaction. The electrochemical processes are of great importance in the laboratory and the chemical industry. One of the simplest electrolytic cell consists of two copper strips dipping in an aqueous solution of copper sulphate. If a DC voltage is applied to the two electrodes, then $\mathrm { C u } ^ { \bar { 2 } + }$ ions discharge at the cathode (negatively charged) and the follwing reaction takes place: 

Copper metal is deposited on the cathode. At the anode, copper is converted into $\mathrm { { C u } ^ { 2 + } }$ ions by the reaction: 

Thus copper is dissolved (oxidised) at anode and deposited (reduced) at cathode. This is the basis for an industrial process in which impure copper is converted into copper of high purity. The impure copper is made an anode that dissolves on passing current and pure copper is deposited at the cathode. Many metals like Na, Mg, Al, etc. are produced on large scale by electrochemical reduction of their

The impure copper is made an anode that dissolves on passing current and pure copper is deposited at the cathode. Many metals like Na, Mg, Al, etc. are produced on large scale by electrochemical reduction of their respective cations where no suitable chemical reducing agents are available for this purpose. 

Sodium and magnesium metals are produced by the electrolysis of their fused chlorides and aluminium is produced by electrolysis of aluminium oxide in presence of cryolite. 

Quantitative Aspects of Electrolysis 

Michael Faraday was the first scientist who described the quantitative aspects of electrolysis. Now Faraday's laws also flow from what has been discussed earlier. 

Faraday's Laws of Electrolysis 

After his extensive investigations on electrolysis of solutions and melts of electrolytes, Faraday published his results during 1833-34 in the form of the following well known Faraday's two laws of electrolysis: 

(i) First Law: The amount of chemical reaction which occurs at any electrode during electrolysis by a current is proportional to the quantity of electricity passed through the electrolyte (solution or melt).   
(ii) Second Law: The amounts of different substances liberated by the same quantity of electricity passing through the electrolytic solution are proportional to their chemical equivalent weights (Atomic Mass of Metal $\div$ Number of electrons required to reduce the cation). 

There were no constant current sources available during Faraday's times. The general practice was to put a coulometer (a standard electrolytic cell) for determining the quantity of electricity passed from the amount of metal (generally silver or copper) deposited or consumed. However, coulometers are now obsolete and we now have constant current $\left( I \right)$ sources available and the quantity of electricity $Q$ , passed is given by 

$Q$ is in coloumbs when $I$ is in ampere and $t$ is in second.

The charge passed through the electrolytic cell during electrolysis is equal to the product of current in amperes and time in seconds. 2.5.1 Products of Electrolysis 

Products of electrolysis depend on the nature of material being electrolysed and the type of electrodes being used. If the electrode is inert (e.g., platinum or gold), it does not participate in the chemical reaction and acts only as source or sink for electrons. On the other hand, if the electrode is reactive, it participates in the electrode reaction. Thus, the products of electrolysis may be different for reactive and inert electrodes.The products of electrolysis depend on the different oxidising and reducing species present in the electrolytic cell and their standard electrode potentials. Moreover, some of the electrochemical processes although feasible, are so slow kinetically that at lower voltages these do not seem to take place and extra potential (called overpotential has to be applied, which makes such process more difficult to occur. 

For example, if we use molten NaCl, the products of electrolysis are sodium metal and $\mathrm { C l } _ { 2 }$ gas. Here we have only one cation $\boldsymbol { ( \mathrm { N a ^ { + } ) } }$ which is reduced at the cathode $\mathrm { ( N a ^ { + } + e ^ { - }  N a ) }$ and one anion (Cl) which is oxidised at the anode $\mathrm { ( C l ^ { - }  ^ { 1 } 2 C l _ { 2 } + e ^ { - } }$ ). During the electrolysis of aqueous sodium chloride solution, the products are NaOH, $\mathrm { C l } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 }$ . 2.6 Batteries 

Any battery (actually it may have one or more than one cell connected in series) or cell that we use as a source of electrical energy is basically a galvanic cell where the chemical energy of the redox reaction is converted into electrical energy. However, for a battery to be of practical use it should be reasonably light, compact and its voltage should not vary appreciably during its use. There are mainly two types of batteries. 

2.6.1 Primary Batteries

2.7 fuel Cells 

Production of electricity by thermal plants is not a very efficient method and is a major source of pollution. In such plants, the chemical energy (heat of combustion) of fossil fuels (coal, gas or oil) is first used for converting water into high pressure steam. This is then used to run a turbine to produce electricity. We know that a galvanic cell directly converts chemical energy into electricity and is highly efficient. It is now possible to make such cells in which reactants are fed continuously to the electrodes and products are removed continuously from the electrolyte compartment. Galvanic cells that are designed to convert the energy of combustion of fuels like hydrogen, methane, methanol, etc. directly into electrical energy are called fuel cells. 

One of the most successful fuel cells uses the reaction of hydrogen with oxygen to form water (Fig. 2.12). The cell was used for providing electrical power in the Apollo space programme. The water vapours produced during the reaction were condensed and added to the drinking water supply for the astronauts. In the cell, hydrogen and oxygen are bubbled through porous carbon electrodes into concentrated aqueous sodium hydroxide solution. Catalysts like finely divided platinum or palladium metal are incorporated into the electrodes for increasing the rate of electrode reactions. The electrode reactions are 

given below: 

Overall reaction being: $\mathrm { 2 H _ { 2 } ( g ) + O _ { 2 } ( g ) \longrightarrow 2 H _ { 2 } O ( l ) }$ 

The cell runs continuously as long as the reactants are supplied. Fuel cells produce electricity with an efficiency of about $7 0 \%$ compared to thermal plants whose efficiency is about $4 0 \%$ . There has been tremendous progress in the development of new electrode materials, better catalysts and electrolytes for increasing the efficiency of fuel cells. These have been used in automobiles on an experimental basis. Fuel cells are pollution free and in view of their future importance, a variety of fuel cells have been fabricated and tried.

Corrosion slowly coats the surfaces of metallic objects with oxides or other salts of the metal. The rusting of iron, tarnishing of silver, development of green coating on copper and bronze are some of the examples of corrosion. It causes enormous damage to buildings, bridges, ships and to all objects made of metals especially that of iron. We lose crores of rupees every year on account of corrosion. 

In corrosion, a metal is oxidised by loss of electrons to oxygen and formation of oxides. Corrosion of iron (commonly known as rusting) occurs in presence of water and air. The chemistry of corrosion is quite

chunk-41cbb838c24b15c464f497b7288f4652.content:
, development of green coating on copper and bronze are some of the examples of corrosion. It causes enormous damage to buildings, bridges, ships and to all objects made of metals especially that of iron. We lose crores of rupees every year on account of corrosion. 

In corrosion, a metal is oxidised by loss of electrons to oxygen and formation of oxides. Corrosion of iron (commonly known as rusting) occurs in presence of water and air. The chemistry of corrosion is quite complex but it may be considered essentially as an electrochemical phenomenon. At a particular spot (Fig. 2.13) of an object made of iron, oxidation takes place and that spot behaves as anode and we can write the reaction 

Electrons released at anodic spot move through the metal and go to another spot on the metal and reduce oxygen in the presence of $\mathrm { H } ^ { + }$ (which is believed to be available from $\mathrm { { H _ { 2 } C O _ { 3 } } }$ formed due to dissolution of carbon dioxide from air into water. Hydrogen ion in water may also be available due to dissolution of other acidic oxides from the atmosphere). This spot behaves as cathode with the reaction 

The overall reaction being: 

The ferrous ions are further oxidised by atmospheric oxygen to ferric ions which come out as rust in the form of hydrated ferric oxide $( \mathrm { F e } _ { 2 } \mathrm { O } _ { 3 } . \ x \ \mathrm { H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { O } )$ and with further production of hydrogen ions. 

Prevention of corrosion is of prime importance. It not only saves money but also helps in preventing accidents such as a bridge collapse or failure of a key component due to corrosion. One of the simplest methods of preventing corrosion is to prevent the surface of the metallic object to come in contact with atmosphere. This can be done by covering the surface with paint or by some chemicals (e.g. bisphenol). Another simple method is to cover the surface by other metals (Sn, Zn, etc.) that are inert or react to save the object. An electrochemical method is to provide a sacrificial electrode of another metal (like Mg, Zn, etc.) which corrodes itself but saves the object.

The Hydrogen Economy 

At present the main source of energy that is driving our economy is fossil fuels such as coal, oil and gas. As more people on the planet aspire to improve their standard of living, their energy requirement will increase. In fact, the per capita consumption of energy used is a measure of development. Of course, it is assumed that energy is used for productive purpose and not merely wasted. We are already aware that carbon dioxide produced by the combustion of fossil fuels is resulting in the 'Greenhouse Effect'. This is leading to a rise in the temperature of the Earth's surface, causing polar ice to melt and ocean levels to rise. This will flood low-lying areas along the coast and some island nations such as Maldives face total submergence. In order to avoid such a catastrope, we need to limit our use of carbonaceous fuels. Hydrogen provides an ideal alternative as its combustion results in water only. Hydrogen production must come from splitting water using solar energy. Therefore, hydrogen can be used as a renewable and non polluting source of energy. This is the vision of the Hydrogen Economy. Both the production of hydrogen by electrolysis of water and hydrogen combustion in a fuel cell will be important in the future

Both the production of hydrogen by electrolysis of water and hydrogen combustion in a fuel cell will be important in the future. And both these technologies are based on electrochemical principles. 

Summary 

An electrochemical cell consists of two metalic electrodes dipping in electrolytic solution(s). Thus an important component of the electrochemical cell is the ionic conductor or electrolyte. Electrochemical cells are of two types. In galvanic cell, the chemical energy of a spontaneous redox reaction is converted into electrical work, whereas in an electrolytic cell, electrical energy is used to carry out a nonspontaneous redox reaction. The standard electrode potential for any electrode dipping in an appropriate solution is defined with respect to standard electrode potential of hydrogen electrode taken as zero. The standard potential of the cell an $\ : [ \ : E _ { \mathrm { ( c e l l ) } } ^ { \mathrm { o } } \ : = \ : E ^ { \mathrm { o } } \ :$ catie $E ^ { 0 }$ related to standard Gibbs energy $( \Delta _ { r } G ^ { \mathrm { o } } ~ = ~ - n F E _ { \mathrm { ( c e l l ) } } ^ { \mathrm { o } } )$ and equilibrium constant $( \Delta _ { r } G ^ { \mathrm { o } } = - \ R T \ln \ K )$ of the reaction taking place in the cell. Concentration dependence of the potentials of the electrodes and the cells are given by Nernst equation. 

The conductivity, $\kappa ,$ of an electrolytic solution depends on the concentration of the electrolyte, nature of solvent and temperature. Molar conductivity, $\varLambda _ { m }$ ,is defined by $\quad = \ \kappa / c$ where $c$ is the concentration. Conductivity decreases but molar conductivity increases with decrease in concentration. It increases slowly with decrease in concentration for strong electrolytes while the increase is very steep for weak electrolytes in very dilute solutions. Kohlrausch found that molar conductivity at infinite dilution, for an electrolyte is sum of the contribution of the molar conductivity of the ions in which it dissociates. It is known as law of independent migration of ions and has many applications. Ions conduct electricity through the solution but oxidation and reduction of the ions take place at the electrodes in an electrochemical cell. Batteries and fuel cells are very useful forms of galvanic cell. Corrosion of metals is essentially an electrochemical phenomenon. Electrochemical principles are relevant to the Hydrogen Economy.

Image Content Analysis:
Image Path: /workspace/RAG-System-Chemistry/output/lech102/auto/images/0843587479bcf43c17cf06fa582bf8ea728f2555dcbe4323db6c3d2f99039931.jpg
Captions: None
Footnotes: None

Visual Analysis: The image presents a detailed schematic diagram of a Daniell cell, a classic example of a galvanic (voltaic) cell used to convert chemical energy into electrical energy. The layout is horizontally oriented, showing two separate half-cells connected by a salt bridge. On the left side, there is a zinc electrode immersed in a solution containing Zn2+ ions, represented by a beaker labeled with Zn2+ ions and a Zn metal rod. On the right side, a copper electrode is immersed in a Cu2+ ion solution, similarly depicted with a beaker and a Cu metal rod. The salt bridge, typically a U-shaped tube filled with an electrolyte, connects the two solutions, allowing ion flow to maintain electrical neutrality. Arrows indicate the flow of electrons from the zinc electrode (anode) through an external wire to the copper electrode (cathode), demonstrating the direction of electron movement. The zinc electrode is labeled as the anode where oxidation occurs (Zn dissolves into Zn2+ ions), and the copper electrode is labeled as the cathode where reduction occurs (Cu2+ ions gain electrons and deposit as copper metal). The diagram includes voltage notation showing the cell potential of approximately 1.1 V under standard conditions (1 mol dm^-3 ion concentration). The background is plain white, and the colors used are realistic: metallic gray for electrodes, blue for the Zn2+ solution, and reddish-brown for the Cu2+ solution, enhancing clarity. The image uses clear, legible labels and arrows to explain the electrochemical processes, consistent with the surrounding text that discusses the Daniell cell's construction, function, and the flow of electrons and ions. This visual aids in understanding the conversion of chemical energy to electrical energy and the fundamental operation of galvanic cells, directly supporting the unit's objectives on electrochemical cells and their potentials.

chunk-9ec4f6c3ec35308a062b5af7cbc1e670.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\mathrm { Z n ( s ) + C u ^ { 2 + } ( a q )  Z n ^ { 2 + } ( a q ) + C u ( s ) }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation Zn(s) + Cu^{2+}(aq) → Zn^{2+}(aq) + Cu(s) represents the overall redox reaction occurring in a Daniell galvanic cell. Mathematically, it is a balanced chemical equation describing the transfer of electrons between zinc and copper species. Here, Zn(s) is solid zinc metal, Cu^{2+}(aq) is the aqueous copper ion, Zn^{2+}(aq) is the aqueous zinc ion, and Cu(s) is solid copper metal. The reaction involves oxidation of zinc metal to zinc ions (Zn → Zn^{2+} + 2e^-) and reduction of copper ions to copper metal (Cu^{2+} + 2e^- → Cu). The equation encapsulates the electron transfer process that generates an electromotive force (emf) in the galvanic cell. The mathematical operations implicit include stoichiometric balancing and electron conservation. This reaction is fundamental in electrochemistry, illustrating the conversion of chemical energy into electrical energy. It relates directly to concepts such as electrode potentials, standard reduction potentials, Gibbs free energy change, and the Nernst equation, which quantify the cell's voltage and spontaneity. Practically, this reaction underpins the operation of batteries and electrochemical cells used in energy storage and conversion technologies. Within the broader framework, this equation exemplifies the principles of redox chemistry and electrochemical energy conversion discussed in the unit, serving as a foundational example for understanding galvanic and electrolytic cells, electrode potentials, and related thermodynamic relationships.

The zinc electrode is shown dissolving into Zn2+ ions, while copper ions are shown depositing on the copper electrode, representing the oxidation and reduction reactions respectively. chunk-2153b7cfe4b26a192edea82a3cf5a62d.content:
Image Content Analysis:
Image Path: /workspace/RAG-System-Chemistry/output/lech102/auto/images/fbda57ca10e03cd9500a6dc98767af34686c5d0448a68fd2a7b3bf62456336bc.jpg
Captions: None
Footnotes: None

Visual Analysis: The image is a composite diagram illustrating the functioning of a Daniell cell under the influence of an external opposing voltage, labeled as $E_{ext}$. The layout consists of three distinct panels arranged horizontally, each depicting a different state of the electrochemical cell. Each panel shows a Daniell cell setup with two electrodes: a zinc (Zn) electrode on the left and a copper (Cu) electrode on the right, both immersed in their respective ionic solutions. The electrodes are connected externally by a wire, and a voltmeter is shown measuring the cell potential. The first panel (Fig. 2.2(a)) shows the Daniell cell operating spontaneously with electron flow from the zinc electrode (anode) to the copper electrode (cathode), generating an electrical current. The second panel (Fig. 2.2(b)) depicts the condition when the external voltage opposing the cell potential is increased to exactly 1.1 V, the standard emf of the Daniell cell. At this point, the reaction ceases, no electron flow occurs, and the voltmeter reads zero current. The third panel (Fig. 2.2(c)) illustrates the scenario where the external voltage exceeds 1.1 V, reversing the direction of electron flow and causing the cell to function as an electrolytic cell. Here, the non-spontaneous reaction is driven by the external power source, reversing the redox processes at the electrodes. The color scheme uses metallic gray for electrodes, blue for the copper sulfate solution, and a lighter blue or transparent color for the zinc sulfate solution, emphasizing the different electrolytes. Arrows indicate the direction of electron flow and current in each panel, with labels clarifying the processes occurring at the anode and cathode. The visual style is schematic and educational, with clear, labeled components and simplified representations to aid understanding. This image directly relates to the surrounding text explaining the transition between galvanic and electrolytic cell behavior in the Daniell cell, illustrating the effect of applying an external voltage opposing the cell's emf.

chunk-bed2372fe413aeef8472e79a0b1cb72e.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\mathrm { { Z n } ( s ) + \mathrm { { C u } ^ { 2 + } ( a q )  \mathrm { { Z n } ^ { 2 + } \ ( a q ) + \mathrm { { C u } ( s ) } } } }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation represents the overall redox reaction occurring in a Daniell cell, a classic galvanic cell. Mathematically, it is a balanced chemical equation showing the transformation of reactants to products. Here, Zn(s) denotes solid zinc metal, Cu^{2+}(aq) is the aqueous copper ion with a +2 charge, Zn^{2+}(aq) is the aqueous zinc ion with a +2 charge, and Cu(s) is solid copper metal. The equation describes the oxidation of zinc metal to zinc ions and the simultaneous reduction of copper ions to copper metal. The reaction involves electron transfer: zinc loses two electrons (oxidation) and copper ions gain two electrons (reduction). This redox process generates an electromotive force (emf) that drives electron flow through an external circuit, converting chemical energy into electrical energy. The equation is fundamental in electrochemistry, illustrating the principle of galvanic cells, electrode potentials, and the relationship between chemical reactions and electrical work. It connects to concepts such as half-cell reactions, standard electrode potentials, and cell emf. Practically, this reaction underpins batteries and electrochemical cells used in energy storage and conversion devices. Within the broader discussion, this equation exemplifies the chemical basis for the Daniell cell's operation, linking chemical thermodynamics and electrochemical principles to real-world applications in energy technology.

chunk-c306a618216692564bc4cfb617ee4053.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { r l } { \mathrm { C u ^ { 2 + } } } & { + \mathrm { \small ~ 2 e ^ { - } ~ }  \mathrm { C u ( s ) } \qquad \mathrm { ( r e d u c t i o n ~ h a l f ~ r e a c t i o n ) } } \\ { \mathrm { Z n ( s ) } } & {  \mathrm { Z n ^ { 2 + } } + \mathrm { 2 e ^ { - } } \qquad \mathrm { ( o x i d a t i o n ~ h a l f ~ r e a c t i o n ) } } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The given equation represents the two half-reactions occurring in a Daniell galvanic cell, a fundamental electrochemical system. The first half-reaction is the reduction of copper ions (Cu^{2+}) by gaining two electrons (2e^-) to form solid copper (Cu(s)), while the second half-reaction is the oxidation of solid zinc (Zn(s)) to zinc ions (Zn^{2+}) by losing two electrons. These half-reactions are complementary redox processes: the reduction half-cell involves electron gain, and the oxidation half-cell involves electron loss. The variables Cu^{2+} and Zn^{2+} denote the ionic species in aqueous solution, and e^- represents electrons transferred through the external circuit. The mathematical operations include electron transfer balancing and stoichiometric coefficients ensuring charge and mass conservation. This equation is central to electrochemistry, illustrating the conversion of chemical energy into electrical energy via spontaneous redox reactions. It relates directly to the cell potential (emf) discussed in the context, which is the difference in electrode potentials of the cathode and anode. The equation underpins the theoretical framework for galvanic cells, standard electrode potentials, and the Nernst equation, which quantifies cell potential under non-standard conditions. Practically, it explains the working principle of batteries, corrosion processes, and electroplating. Within the broader discussion, this equation exemplifies the fundamental redox chemistry enabling the Daniell cell's function as a source of electrical energy and sets the stage for analyzing cell potentials and electrochemical series.

chunk-f7a6196c2c386b13c12c240d1eac4ef3.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
E _ { \mathrm { c e l l } } = E _ { \mathrm { r i g h t } } - E _ { \mathrm { l e f t } }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation $E_{\mathrm{cell}} = E_{\mathrm{right}} - E_{\mathrm{left}}$ mathematically expresses the electromotive force (emf) or cell potential of a galvanic cell as the difference between the electrode potentials of the cathode (right half-cell) and the anode (left half-cell). Here, $E_{\mathrm{cell}}$ represents the overall cell potential measured in volts (V), $E_{\mathrm{right}}$ is the standard electrode potential of the cathode where reduction occurs, and $E_{\mathrm{left}}$ is the standard electrode potential of the anode where oxidation occurs. The subtraction operation reflects the potential difference driving electron flow from anode to cathode. This equation is fundamental in electrochemistry, linking thermodynamic spontaneity of redox reactions to measurable electrical energy output. It relies on the convention that the anode is placed on the left and the cathode on the right in cell notation. The electrode potentials are standard reduction potentials measured under standard conditions (1 M concentration, 1 bar pressure, 298 K). Physically, this potential difference corresponds to the Gibbs free energy change of the redox reaction, enabling conversion of chemical energy into electrical work. The equation is central to understanding galvanic cells like the Daniell cell, standard hydrogen electrode referencing, and the calculation of cell emf for various electrochemical systems. It connects to concepts such as half-cell reactions, redox couples, and standard electrode potentials, providing a quantitative framework for predicting cell voltage and direction of electron flow. Practically, it underpins the design and analysis of batteries, fuel cells, and electrochemical sensors, facilitating the harnessing of spontaneous redox reactions for electrical power generation. Within the broader discussion, this equation formalizes the relationship between individual half-cell potentials and the overall cell voltage, serving as a cornerstone for interpreting and constructing galvanic cells and their standard potentials.

chunk-f3fed4d17f9562b37ce9a7f7e9885439.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\mathrm { C u ( s ) } + 2 \mathrm { A g } ^ { + } \mathrm { ( a q ) } \longrightarrow \mathrm { C u } ^ { 2 + } \mathrm { ( a q ) } + 2 \mathrm { ~ A g ( s ) }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation represents a redox reaction occurring in a galvanic cell, specifically involving copper and silver species. Mathematically, it is a balanced chemical equation showing the stoichiometric relationship between reactants and products. The variables are chemical species: Cu(s) denotes solid copper metal, Ag+(aq) denotes silver ions in aqueous solution, Cu2+(aq) denotes copper ions in aqueous solution, and Ag(s) denotes solid silver metal. The coefficients indicate the molar ratios: 1 mole of copper reacts with 2 moles of silver ions to produce 1 mole of copper ions and 2 moles of silver metal atoms. The arrow indicates the direction of the spontaneous reaction. This reaction is a combination of two half-reactions: oxidation of copper metal to copper ions and reduction of silver ions to silver metal. The equation exemplifies the electron transfer process fundamental to galvanic cells, where chemical energy is converted into electrical energy. It relates to the broader framework of electrochemistry by illustrating how redox couples form half-cells, and their potentials determine the cell's electromotive force (emf). The reaction's stoichiometry is essential for calculating cell potentials using the Nernst equation and for understanding the flow of electrons through the external circuit. Practically, this reaction underpins the operation of galvanic cells used in batteries and electroplating, demonstrating the principles of electrode potentials and spontaneous redox processes.
chunk-f3fed4d17f9562b37ce9a7f7e9885439.modal_entity_name: Copper-Silver Redox Reaction in Galvanic Cell (equation)

chunk-a9f108d2abb5d2e118ef2ed9892c5cef.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { l } { { \mathrm { C a t h o d e ~ } ( r e d u c t i o n ) { : } \quad 2 \mathrm { A g } ^ { + } ( \mathrm { a q } ) + 2 \mathrm { e } ^ { - }  2 \mathrm { A g } \mathrm { ( s ) } } } \\ { { \mathrm { A n o d e ~ } ( o x i d a t i o n ) { : } \qquad \mathrm { C u ( s ) } \quad  \mathrm { C u } ^ { 2 + } ( \mathrm { a q } ) + 2 \mathrm { e } ^ { - } } } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The given equation represents the half-cell reactions occurring in a galvanic cell, specifically the Daniell cell variant involving silver and copper electrodes. Mathematically, it consists of two half-reactions: the cathode (reduction) reaction and the anode (oxidation) reaction. The cathode half-reaction is 2Ag⁺(aq) + 2e⁻ → 2Ag(s), where silver ions in aqueous solution gain electrons (reduction) to form solid silver. The anode half-reaction is Cu(s) → Cu²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻, where solid copper loses electrons (oxidation) to form copper ions in solution. Variables include Ag⁺ and Cu²⁺ representing ionic species in aqueous phase, e⁻ as electrons, and Ag(s), Cu(s) as solid metal electrodes. The operations involve electron transfer, oxidation-reduction processes, and stoichiometric balancing of electrons to maintain charge conservation. This equation is fundamental in electrochemistry, illustrating redox processes that generate electrical energy from chemical reactions. It relates to the concept of electrode potentials, cell emf, and galvanic cell construction discussed in the context. The theoretical significance lies in demonstrating how spontaneous redox reactions drive electron flow through an external circuit, enabling practical applications such as batteries and electrochemical sensors. The equation also connects to standard electrode potentials and the use of reference electrodes like the standard hydrogen electrode. Overall, it exemplifies the core principles of electrochemical energy conversion within the broader framework of galvanic cell operation and electrochemical thermodynamics.
chunk-a9f108d2abb5d2e118ef2ed9892c5cef.modal_entity_name: Half-cell redox reactions in a silver-copper galvanic cell (equation)

Captions: None
Footnotes: None

Visual Analysis: The image depicts a detailed schematic diagram of the Standard Hydrogen Electrode (SHE), labeled as Fig. 2.3, used for the measurement of electrode potential. The composition is centered around a vertical cylindrical container filled with an acidic aqueous solution, indicated by a light blue color representing the electrolyte containing hydrogen ions (H+). A platinum electrode, shown as a solid black vertical rod, is immersed in the solution. The platinum electrode is coated with a textured layer labeled 'platinum black,' which increases the surface area for the redox reaction. At the top of the container, pure hydrogen gas (H2) is bubbled through a tube connected to the solution, represented by small bubbles rising from the electrode surface. The gas is maintained at a pressure of 1 bar, as indicated by a label near the gas inlet. The concentration of hydrogen ions in the solution is maintained at 1 molar, consistent with standard conditions. The diagram includes labels for each component: 'Pt electrode,' 'H2 gas (1 bar),' 'H+ (1 M),' and 'acidic solution.' The container is shown with a boundary line, and the interface between the platinum electrode and the electrolyte is clearly marked, emphasizing the electrode-electrolyte interface where the redox reaction occurs. The visual style is technical and schematic, using clear lines and color coding to distinguish elements. The lighting is uniform, typical of scientific diagrams, with no shadows or three-dimensional effects. The image relates directly to the surrounding text, which explains the function and construction of the Standard Hydrogen Electrode as a reference half-cell with zero electrode potential, used to measure the electrode potentials of other half-cells. The diagram visually supports the explanation of the SHE's components and operating conditions, such as the use of platinum black to facilitate electron transfer and the maintenance of standard hydrogen ion concentration and gas pressure. No additional technical charts or graphs are present, but the image serves as a precise visual aid for understanding the electrochemical setup described in the text.

chunk-af28e209e52631fdf98c8503141813d9.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\mathrm { H } ^ { + } \ ( \mathrm { a q } ) + \mathrm { e } ^ { - } \  \ \frac { 1 } { 2 } \mathrm { H } _ { 2 } ( \mathrm { g } )
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation \( \mathrm{H}^+ (\mathrm{aq}) + e^- \rightarrow \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{H}_2 (\mathrm{g}) \) represents the half-cell reaction occurring at the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE), which is the fundamental reference electrode in electrochemistry. Mathematically, it describes the reduction of hydrogen ions (protons) in aqueous solution by gaining electrons to form hydrogen gas molecules. Here, \( \mathrm{H}^+ (\mathrm{aq}) \) denotes the hydrogen ion in aqueous phase, \( e^- \) is the electron, and \( \mathrm{H}_2 (\mathrm{g}) \) is diatomic hydrogen gas in gaseous phase. The fractional coefficient \( \frac{1}{2} \) indicates that one electron reduces one proton to half a hydrogen molecule, consistent with stoichiometry. The operation is a redox half-reaction involving electron transfer and phase change. This half-reaction is central to defining the standard electrode potential, assigned zero volts by convention at standard conditions (1 M concentration, 1 bar pressure, 298 K). It serves as the baseline for measuring electrode potentials of other half-cells, enabling calculation of cell electromotive force (emf) by difference of potentials. The equation is foundational in electrochemical thermodynamics, linking Gibbs free energy changes to electrical work. It underpins the construction and analysis of galvanic cells, such as the Daniell cell, by providing a reference for oxidation-reduction potential measurements. Practically, it is used to calibrate electrodes and interpret redox behavior in batteries, corrosion, and electrolysis. The equation relates to broader concepts of redox chemistry, electrode potentials, and electrochemical cell design discussed in the context, illustrating the fundamental process by which chemical energy is converted to electrical energy in galvanic cells.

chunk-6b78bd23e584b889b31ba8d3ecc775de.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
E ^ { \mathrm { o } } = E _ { \mathrm { ~ \tiny ~ R ~ } } ^ { \mathrm { o } } - E _ { \mathrm { ~ \tiny ~ L ~ } } ^ { \mathrm { o } }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation $E^{\mathrm{o}} = E_{\mathrm{R}}^{\mathrm{o}} - E_{\mathrm{L}}^{\mathrm{o}}$ represents the standard electromotive force (emf) of a galvanic cell, defined as the difference between the standard electrode potentials of the right (cathode) and left (anode) half-cells. Here, $E^{\mathrm{o}}$ denotes the overall standard cell potential, $E_{\mathrm{R}}^{\mathrm{o}}$ is the standard reduction potential of the cathode half-cell, and $E_{\mathrm{L}}^{\mathrm{o}}$ is the standard reduction potential of the anode half-cell. The equation involves subtraction of scalar quantities measured in volts (V), reflecting the potential difference driving electron flow in the electrochemical cell. This formulation is grounded in electrochemical conventions where the anode is placed on the left and the cathode on the right in cell notation. The standard electrode potentials are measured under standard conditions (1 M concentration, 1 bar pressure, 25°C) relative to the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE), which is assigned zero potential. The equation encapsulates the fundamental principle that the cell emf arises from the difference in the tendency of two half-reactions to gain electrons (reduction). It is central to understanding redox reactions, predicting spontaneity, and calculating thermodynamic properties such as Gibbs free energy change. This relationship is foundational in electrochemistry, linking half-cell potentials to the overall cell voltage, and is instrumental in applications including corrosion analysis, battery design, and electrochemical synthesis. The equation also serves as a precursor to the Nernst equation, which generalizes cell potential under non-standard conditions.

chunk-f37c6a6479ac11d8ed602ec125d2a7a0.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { r } { \boldsymbol { { E } } ^ { \mathrm { { o } } } = \boldsymbol { { E } } _ { \mathrm { ~ R ~ } } ^ { \mathrm { { o } } } - \boldsymbol { 0 } = \boldsymbol { { E } } _ { \mathrm { ~ R ~ } } ^ { \mathrm { { o } } } } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation \( \mathbf{E}^\mathrm{o} = \mathbf{E}_{\mathrm{R}}^\mathrm{o} - 0 = \mathbf{E}_{\mathrm{R}}^\mathrm{o} \) represents the standard electrode potential of a half-cell reaction relative to the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE). Mathematically, it states that the standard electrode potential \( \mathbf{E}^\mathrm{o} \) of the half-cell is equal to the reduction potential \( \mathbf{E}_{\mathrm{R}}^\mathrm{o} \) of the right-hand half-cell minus the standard electrode potential of the left-hand half-cell, which is zero by convention for the SHE. Here, \( \mathbf{E}^\mathrm{o} \) is the measurable electromotive force (emf) under standard conditions (1 M concentration, 1 bar pressure, 298 K temperature). The variable \( \mathbf{E}_{\mathrm{R}}^\mathrm{o} \) denotes the standard reduction potential of the half-cell under investigation. The subtraction of zero reflects the choice of the SHE as the reference electrode with assigned zero potential. The equation involves simple arithmetic subtraction and equality relations. This equation is fundamental in electrochemistry for determining the relative tendency of species to gain electrons (be reduced) compared to hydrogen ions. It underpins the construction of electrochemical series and the calculation of cell potentials. The physical significance lies in quantifying the driving force for redox reactions and predicting spontaneity. It relates directly to the Nernst equation and the concept of standard states. Practically, it enables the measurement of unknown electrode potentials by pairing with the SHE, facilitating applications such as corrosion analysis, battery design, and electroplating. Within the broader framework, this equation establishes the baseline for all electrode potential measurements and standardizes electrochemical data, allowing consistent comparison across different half-cell reactions.
chunk-f37c6a6479ac11d8ed602ec125d2a7a0.modal_entity_name: Standard Electrode Potential Relative to Standard Hydrogen Electrode (equation)

chunk-969a191d84fc943c828fc5b817e6c907.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\mathrm { C u } ^ { 2 + } ~ ( \mathrm { a q } , ~ 1 \mathrm { M } ) + 2 ~ \mathrm { e } ^ { - } ~  ~ \mathrm { C u ( s ) }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation \( \mathrm{Cu}^{2+} (\mathrm{aq}, 1 \mathrm{M}) + 2 \mathrm{e}^- \rightarrow \mathrm{Cu} (\mathrm{s}) \) represents a half-cell reduction reaction in electrochemistry, specifically the reduction of copper ions to solid copper metal. Mathematically, it describes the gain of two electrons (\(2 \mathrm{e}^-\)) by copper ions (\(\mathrm{Cu}^{2+}\)) in aqueous solution at unit molar concentration, resulting in the deposition of copper metal. The variables include \(\mathrm{Cu}^{2+}\), the copper ion in aqueous phase, and \(\mathrm{e}^-\), electrons supplied by the external circuit. The reaction is a redox half-reaction, fundamental to galvanic cells, where it typically occurs at the cathode. The stoichiometric coefficient 2 indicates the number of electrons involved per copper ion reduced. This half-reaction is central to determining the standard electrode potential \(E^0\) of the copper half-cell, which quantifies its tendency to gain electrons relative to the standard hydrogen electrode. The equation is used in the context of electrochemical cells to calculate cell potentials, predict reaction spontaneity, and understand electron transfer processes. It relates to the broader framework of electrochemical thermodynamics, including the Nernst equation, which adjusts electrode potentials for non-standard conditions. Practically, this reaction underpins copper plating, corrosion processes, and electrorefining. It also serves as a reference for comparing oxidizing and reducing strengths of various species in aqueous solutions.

chunk-6e5c30fa3f6a766f2ac999d5f5902bde.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { r l } & { \mathrm { Z n ( s ) } \ + \ \mathrm { C u } ^ { 2 + } \ \mathrm { ( a q ) } \ \to \ \mathrm { Z n } ^ { 2 + } \ \mathrm { ( a q ) } \ + \ \mathrm { C u ( s ) } } \\ & { \mathrm { e m f ~ o f ~ t h e ~ c e l l } \ = \ E _ { \mathrm {  ~ { c e l l } } } ^ { 0 } \ = \ E _ { \mathrm {  ~ { R } } } ^ { 0 } - \ E _ { \mathrm {  ~ { L } } } ^ { 0 } } \\ & { \qquad = 0 . 3 4 \mathrm { V } \ - \ ( - 0 . 7 6 ) \mathrm { V } = \ 1 . 1 0 \ \mathrm { V } } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation represents the overall redox reaction occurring in a Daniell galvanic cell, where solid zinc (Zn) is oxidized to zinc ions (Zn^{2+}) in aqueous solution, and copper ions (Cu^{2+}) in aqueous solution are reduced to solid copper (Cu). Mathematically, the cell electromotive force (emf), denoted as E_cell^0, is expressed as the difference between the standard reduction potentials of the cathode (right electrode, E_R^0) and the anode (left electrode, E_L^0). Here, E_cell^0 = E_R^0 - E_L^0 = 0.34 V - (-0.76 V) = 1.10 V. The variables E_R^0 and E_L^0 represent the standard electrode potentials of the copper and zinc half-cells respectively, measured under standard conditions (1 M concentration, 1 bar pressure, 25°C). The subtraction reflects the convention that the cell potential is the cathode potential minus the anode potential, ensuring a positive emf for spontaneous reactions. This equation employs basic arithmetic operations (subtraction) and the concept of standard electrode potentials from electrochemistry. The physical significance lies in quantifying the maximum possible voltage the galvanic cell can deliver, which corresponds to the Gibbs free energy change driving the redox reaction. It relates to the broader framework of electrochemical cells, standard hydrogen electrode reference potentials, and the determination of redox tendencies of metals. Practically, this equation is fundamental in designing batteries, understanding corrosion, and electroplating processes. It also exemplifies how standard electrode potentials can be combined to predict cell voltages and reaction spontaneity in electrochemical systems.

chunk-df170278171f190db65c0d5f612b13ac.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\mathbb { M } ^ { \mathrm { n + } } ( \mathrm { a q } ) + \mathrm { n e } ^ { - } \to \mathbb { M } ( \mathrm { s } )
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation \( \mathbb{M}^{\mathrm{n+}} (\mathrm{aq}) + n e^- \to \mathbb{M} (\mathrm{s}) \) represents a generic half-cell redox reaction where a metal ion \( \mathbb{M}^{\mathrm{n+}} \) in aqueous solution gains \( n \) electrons to form the solid metal \( \mathbb{M} \). Mathematically, this is a reduction half-reaction describing the transfer of electrons (reduction) at the electrode interface. The variables are: \( \mathbb{M}^{\mathrm{n+}} \) (aqueous metal ion with charge +n), \( e^- \) (electron), and \( \mathbb{M} \) (solid metal). The reaction is fundamental in electrochemistry, serving as the basis for defining electrode potentials. The equation is used in conjunction with the Nernst equation to relate electrode potential to ion concentration, temperature, and constants such as the gas constant \( R \) and Faraday constant \( F \). Physically, it models the redox process at the electrode surface, crucial for understanding cell emf, standard electrode potentials, and redox equilibria. It connects to the broader framework of electrochemical cells, standard hydrogen electrode reference, and the determination of thermodynamic properties via measured potentials. Practically, it underpins applications in galvanic cells, corrosion, electroplating, and analytical techniques like potentiometric titrations and pH measurements.
chunk-df170278171f190db65c0d5f612b13ac.modal_entity_name: Generic Metal Ion Reduction Half-Cell Reaction (equation)

chunk-028712ca7cbdf31c607efa137df02041.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
E _ { \left( \mathrm { M } ^ { \mathrm { n + } } / \mathrm { M } \right) } = E _ { \left( \mathrm { M } ^ { \mathrm { n + } } / \mathrm { M } \right) } ^ { \mathrm { o } } \ - \ \frac { R T } { n F } \ \ln \frac { \left[ \mathrm { M } \right] } { \left[ \mathrm { M } ^ { \mathrm { n + } } \right] }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The given equation is the Nernst equation, which relates the electrode potential of a redox couple to the standard electrode potential and the activities (or concentrations) of the oxidized and reduced species involved. Mathematically, it expresses the electrode potential E for the half-cell reaction involving the redox pair M^{n+}/M as a function of temperature (T), gas constant (R), number of electrons transferred (n), Faraday constant (F), and the ratio of concentrations of the reduced form [M] and oxidized form [M^{n+}]. Here, E_{(M^{n+}/M)} is the electrode potential under non-standard conditions, E_{(M^{n+}/M)}^0 is the standard electrode potential measured under standard conditions (1 M concentration, 1 bar pressure, 298 K), R = 8.314 J K^{-1} mol^{-1} is the universal gas constant, T is the absolute temperature in kelvin, n is the number of electrons involved in the redox reaction, and F = 96487 C mol^{-1} is the Faraday constant. The logarithmic term accounts for the deviation from standard conditions by incorporating the ratio of the activities (or concentrations) of the reduced and oxidized species. The equation assumes the activity of the solid metal M is unity since it is a pure solid phase. This equation is fundamental in electrochemistry for calculating the electrode potential at any given concentration, thus extending the concept of standard electrode potentials to real-world conditions. It is derived from the Gibbs free energy relationship and the equilibrium constant expression for the redox reaction. The Nernst equation is crucial for understanding and predicting the behavior of electrochemical cells, including galvanic cells, concentration cells, and sensors such as pH meters. It also underpins the interpretation of redox equilibria and the determination of thermodynamic properties in electrochemical systems. Within the broader context, this equation connects the standard electrode potentials tabulated for various half-reactions to practical measurements of cell potentials under varying concentrations, enabling the quantitative analysis of redox reactions and their spontaneity under non-standard conditions.

chunk-88a5bf9d2615d1c1ce5ed3f5e13d3c47.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
E _ { \left( \mathrm { M } ^ { \mathrm { n + } } / \mathrm { M } \right) } = E _ { \left( \mathrm { M } ^ { \mathrm { n + } } / \mathrm { M } \right) } ^ { \mathrm { o } } \ - \ \frac { R T } { n F } \ \mathrm { l n } \frac { 1 } { [ \mathrm { M } ^ { \mathrm { n + } } ] }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation presented is the Nernst equation, which mathematically relates the electrode potential of a half-cell reaction to the standard electrode potential and the concentration (activity) of the ionic species involved. Specifically, it expresses the electrode potential E for the redox couple M^{n+}/M as a function of the standard electrode potential E^0, the universal gas constant R, the absolute temperature T, the number of electrons transferred n, the Faraday constant F, and the concentration of the oxidized species [M^{n+}]. The term ln(1/[M^{n+}]) can be rewritten as -ln([M^{n+}]), indicating that the electrode potential decreases logarithmically with increasing ion concentration. The variables are defined as follows: E_{(M^{n+}/M)} is the electrode potential under non-standard conditions; E^0_{(M^{n+}/M)} is the standard electrode potential measured under standard conditions (1 M concentration, 1 bar pressure, 298 K); R = 8.314 J K^{-1} mol^{-1} is the universal gas constant; T is the temperature in kelvin; n is the number of electrons transferred in the half-reaction; F = 96487 C mol^{-1} is the Faraday constant; and [M^{n+}] is the molar concentration of the metal ion in solution. The equation assumes the activity of the solid metal M is unity since it is a pure solid phase. Mathematically, the equation is derived from the Gibbs free energy change and the relationship between free energy and electromotive force. It incorporates logarithmic and linear operations and is fundamental in electrochemistry for calculating cell potentials under non-standard conditions. The Nernst equation is crucial for understanding how changes in ion concentration affect the redox potential, enabling the prediction of cell behavior in real-world scenarios where concentrations deviate from standard states. It connects thermodynamics with electrochemical measurements and is widely applied in determining pH, solubility products, equilibrium constants, and in potentiometric titrations. Within the broader context of the discussion on standard electrode potentials and electrochemical cells, this equation extends the concept of standard potentials to practical conditions, providing a quantitative tool to analyze and predict the direction and magnitude of redox reactions in electrochemical cells.

The reactions include various elements and compounds such as F2, Cl2, MnO4-, O2, Ag+, Fe3+, Cu2+, H+, Pb2+, Zn2+, Mg2+, Na+, K+, and Li+, among others. The electrode potentials range from a high of +2.87 V for fluorine gas reduction to a low of -3.05 V for lithium ion reduction. Key patterns include a general decrease in electrode potential from top to bottom, indicating a decrease in oxidizing power of the species on the left and an increase in reducing power of the species on the right. Fluorine (F2) has the highest positive electrode potential, confirming it as the strongest oxidizing agent, while lithium ion has the lowest, making lithium metal the strongest reducing agent. The table supports the surrounding content by illustrating the concept that positive E° values correspond to species more stable in their reduced form than hydrogen gas, and negative values indicate species less stable than hydrogen gas. This data is fundamental for understanding redox behavior, predicting reaction spontaneity, and designing electrochemical cells, as discussed in the context. chunk-2c2d5ffeb18e69ffe13c42ca98af26e9.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { r } { E _ { \left( \mathrm { C u } ^ { 2 + } / \mathrm { C u } \right) } \ = \ E _ { \left( \mathrm { C u } ^ { 2 + } / \mathrm { C u } \right) } ^ { \circ } \ - \ \frac { R T } { 2 F } \ \ln \frac { 1 } { \left[ \mathrm { C u } ^ { 2 + } \left( \mathrm { a q } \right) \right] } } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: This equation represents the Nernst equation applied specifically to the copper redox half-cell reaction involving the Cu^{2+}/Cu couple. Mathematically, it expresses the electrode potential E_{(Cu^{2+}/Cu)} as a function of the standard electrode potential E_{(Cu^{2+}/Cu)}^\circ, temperature T, universal gas constant R, Faraday's constant F, and the activity (or concentration) of the aqueous copper ion species [Cu^{2+}]. The equation is derived from thermodynamic principles relating Gibbs free energy changes to electrochemical potential. The logarithmic term \ln(1/[Cu^{2+}]) indicates that the electrode potential increases as the concentration of Cu^{2+} decreases, reflecting the inverse relationship between ion concentration and electrode potential. The factor 2 in the denominator corresponds to the number of electrons transferred in the half-reaction (Cu^{2+} + 2e^- \rightarrow Cu). This equation is fundamental in electrochemistry for calculating the actual electrode potential under non-standard conditions, enabling prediction of cell voltage in galvanic cells such as the Daniell cell. It connects to the broader framework of redox chemistry, equilibrium thermodynamics, and electrochemical kinetics, and is essential for understanding how concentration changes affect cell potential and reaction spontaneity. Practically, it is used to determine cell voltages, analyze reaction equilibria, and calculate equilibrium constants from measured potentials, thereby linking electrochemical measurements to chemical thermodynamics.
chunk-2c2d5ffeb18e69ffe13c42ca98af26e9.modal_entity_name: Nernst Equation for Copper Electrode Potential (equation)

chunk-168cf1a818b93eac9ad604d7005fcd0b.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
{ \cal E } _ { \left( \mathrm { z n } ^ { 2 + } / \mathrm { Z n } \right) } = { \cal E } _ { \left( \mathrm { Z n } ^ { 2 + } / \mathrm { Z n } \right) } ^ { \circ } - \frac { R T } { 2 F } \ln \frac { 1 } { \left[ \mathrm { Z n } ^ { 2 + } \left( \mathrm { a q } \right) \right] }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: This equation represents the Nernst equation applied to the zinc half-cell redox reaction Zn^{2+} + 2e^- ⇌ Zn(s). It expresses the electrode potential \( {\cal E}_{(\mathrm{Zn}^{2+}/\mathrm{Zn})} \) as a function of the standard electrode potential \( {\cal E}^\circ_{(\mathrm{Zn}^{2+}/\mathrm{Zn})} \), temperature T, universal gas constant R, Faraday constant F, and the activity (or effective concentration) of the zinc ion in aqueous solution \( [\mathrm{Zn}^{2+}(aq)] \). The logarithmic term \( \ln \frac{1}{[\mathrm{Zn}^{2+}]} \) reflects the dependence of the electrode potential on ion concentration, indicating that as the concentration of Zn^{2+} decreases, the electrode potential increases. The factor 2 in the denominator corresponds to the number of electrons transferred in the half-reaction (n=2). Mathematically, the equation is derived from the Gibbs free energy relation and the electrochemical potential, linking thermodynamics to electrochemistry. This equation is fundamental in electrochemical cells, such as the Daniell cell, to calculate the actual electrode potential under non-standard conditions. It connects to the broader framework of redox chemistry, equilibrium thermodynamics, and electrochemical kinetics, enabling the prediction of cell voltage changes due to concentration variations. Practically, it is used to determine cell potentials, analyze reaction spontaneity, and calculate equilibrium constants for redox reactions in aqueous media at a given temperature (here, 298 K).
chunk-168cf1a818b93eac9ad604d7005fcd0b.modal_entity_name: Nernst Equation for Zinc Electrode Potential (equation)

chunk-c52cd6e245b8a102cc78e47cda9c65e8.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { r l } { \varepsilon } & { E _ { ( \mathrm { C u ^ { 2 + } / C u } ) } ^ { 0 } \ - \ \frac { R T } { 2 F } \ \ln \ \frac { 1 } { [ \ C \mathrm { U ^ { 2 + } } ( \mathrm { a q } ) ] } \ - \ E _ { ( \mathrm { z n ^ { 2 + } / Z n } ) } ^ { 0 } \ + \ \frac { R T } { 2 F } \ \ln \frac { 1 } { [ Z \mathrm { n ^ { 2 + } } ( \mathrm { a c } } } \\ & { \mathrm { ~ } } \\ { \varepsilon } & { E _ { ( \mathrm { C u ^ { 2 + } / C u } ) } ^ { 0 } \cdot \ E _ { ( \mathrm { z n ^ { 2 + } / Z n } ) } ^ { 0 } \cdot \frac { R T } { 2 F } \ \ln \frac { 1 } { [ \ C \mathrm { u ^ { 2 + } } ( \mathrm { a q } ) ] } \ - \ln \frac { 1 } { [ Z \mathrm { n ^ { 2 + } } ( \mathrm { a q } ) ] } } \\ & { } \\ { E _ { ( \mathrm { c e l l } ) } = \ \stackrel { \cdot } { E _ { ( \mathrm { c e l l } ) } ^ { 0 } } \ - \ \frac { R T } { 2 F } \ \ln \frac { [ Z \mathrm { n ^ { 2 + } } ] } { [ \mathrm { C u ^ { 2 + } } ] } \ } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation presented is a specific form of the Nernst equation applied to the Daniell cell, which consists of copper and zinc electrodes. Mathematically, it expresses the cell potential (E_cell) as a function of the standard electrode potentials of the copper and zinc half-cells (E⁰_(Cu²⁺/Cu) and E⁰_(Zn²⁺/Zn)) and the concentrations of their respective ions in aqueous solution. The variables include R (universal gas constant), T (absolute temperature in Kelvin), F (Faraday's constant), and the ionic concentrations [Cu²⁺] and [Zn²⁺]. The equation uses logarithmic functions (natural logarithm ln) to relate the electrochemical potential to ion activities, reflecting the thermodynamic driving force for electron transfer. The factor 2 in the denominator corresponds to the number of electrons transferred in the redox reaction. This equation is fundamental in electrochemistry for predicting cell voltage under non-standard conditions, linking thermodynamics with measurable electrical quantities. It also connects to equilibrium concepts, as the cell potential approaches zero at equilibrium, allowing calculation of equilibrium constants from standard potentials. Practically, it is used to analyze and design galvanic cells, batteries, and corrosion processes, and to understand redox behavior in aqueous solutions. Within the broader framework, this equation exemplifies how electrochemical potentials depend on ion concentrations and temperature, integrating chemical thermodynamics with electrical measurements.

chunk-3b5761b1eb7cdfe413fdb6e4aa5aa8ce.content:
